DOC.HEAD: West Germany Regains Export Leadership Over U.S.
DOC.NOTE: For Release After 6:30 p.m. EDT. Time Set by source.
DOC.TEXT: West Germany was the world's biggest exporter for the first three months of 1990, regaining its leadership over the United States, the International Monetary Fund reported Sunday. West Germany increased its exports to $99.8 billion, up more than 18 percent over the first quarter of last year. The U.S. increase of nearly 10 percent brought its total to $97.2 billion. In 1989, the United States regained first place with $364 billion worth of exports compared to West Germany's $341 billion. West Germany first forged ahead in 1986. Experts say the economic unification of West Germany and East Germany, which officially began Sunday, could put the united Germany ahead of the U.S. as the world's biggest exporter for years to come. The fund gave no figures for East Germany, which is not among its 151 member countries. Japan trailed in a distant third place with $274 billion worth of exports for 1989 and $68 billion for the first quarter of this year. The United States remained by far the world's biggest importer, with $125 billion in foreign-made goods coming into the country in the first quarter of the year. That compared with $118 billion a year earlier. West Germany's imports also increased, to $78 billion from $65 billion. West Germany had a $22 billion surplus of exports over imports for the quarter, compared with a U.S. deficit of $28 billion. Japan, striving to reduce complaints about its big export surplus, was the only one of the seven major industrial countries to report a drop in exports for the quarter. It still had a $12 billion surplus for the period, second only to West Germany's. The 22 countries that the fund classifies as industrial had a total deficit of $32 billion in trade with the rest of the world for the first quarter of 1990. That was up from $24 billion in the first quarter of 1989. Adding up annual surpluses and deficits for the first time, the fund reported that the industrial countries had an aggregate trade deficit with the rest of the world in 1989 of $110 billion, up from $80 billion in 1988. Italy, along with West Germany, reported the most rapid gains in both imports and exports for the quarter. But because of changes in exchange rates, Italy increased its deficit to $7.3 billion for the quarter, compared with $7.1 billion in the first quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuania's Oil Refinery Back in Business As Blockade Eased
DOC.TEXT: Lithuania's sole oil refinery was back in operation Sunday after the Kremlin eased its embargo on the Baltic republic. Lidia Cheblakova, a duty officer, said the Mazhiekiai Refinery in northwestern Lithuania was receiving 25,000 tons of oil a day, compared to the normal, pre-embargo level of 45,000. Soviet officials resumed pumping oil to Lithuania on Saturday, starting to fulfill its promise to lift the 10-week blockade in return for a moratorium on the republic's declaration of independence. The Soviet government cut off shipments of all oil, most natural gas and numerous other items to Lithuania on April 18 in attempt to force it to rescind its March 11 declaration of independence. The Lithuanian parliament accepted a compromise Friday that traded a 100-day moratorium on the declaration for an immediate end to the blockade and the start of negotiations. The subject of Lithuania's came up in Pope John Paul II's prayers in Rome on Sunday. While he didn't comment on the dispute over independence, the pontiff prayed that conditions would improve for Lithuanian Catholics and that there would be a ``victory of the cross'' in the Soviet republic. Ms. Cheblakova said in a telephone interview the full supply of oil will be resumed as soon as the refinery is ready to receive it. Just one of Mazhiekiai's two plants was operating because there are not enough workers available. Many were released on vacation or laid off when the blockade started, she said. Officials said refined oil from the Mazhiekiai plant, the only one in Lithuania, would not reach consumers for at least two weeks for technical reasons. It refines about 12 million tons of petroleum products a year, a quarter of it used in Lithuania. The refinery employs 2,000 people, who were thrown out of work by the cutoff. The plant processed its last oil April 23 as the blockade exhausted reserves that came from the single pipeline feeding the plant from the Russian city of Polotsk. The huge plant provided much of the gasoline and industrial fuel for Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, the Russian city of Kaliningrad and parts of Byelorussia before it shut down for lack of oil. Lithuania and its 3.8 million people are entirely dependent upon the Soviet Union for its oil and gas, which it receives at highly subsidized prices. Lithuania and its Baltic neighbors, Latvia and Estonia, were independent from Moscow between the two world wars, but were forcibly absorbed back into the Soviet Union by Josef Stalin in 1940. All three are seeking to regain their independence, although Estonia and Latvia have taken a slower approach to separation from the Soviet Union than Lithuania. In his homily, the pope noted that Lithuanian bishops recently celebrated a special Mass in which ``they implored the crucified Christ to shorten the days of difficult testing to which Lithuanian believers continue to be subjected.'' ``May the Lord give them this grace, assuring the victory of the cross,'' the Polish-born pope said. The pontiff, speaking at a Mass at the Lithuanian college of San Casimiro in Rome, said the cross ``has become the special symbol of the Lithuanians: of the people, of the families, of the communities and all the society.'' Soviet authorities in the past have refused John Paul permission to travel to Lithuania, which is overwhelmingly Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Gets Ecstatic Irish Welcome; Says Sanctions Must Stay
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela arrived to a rapturous Irish welcome Sunday, urging that sanctions against South Africa be kept up so that apartheid is ended ``not tomorrow but now.'' The Irish, staunch supporters of the black South African leader, thronged Dawson Street in the center of the capital as Mandela arrived from the United States for a ceremony giving him the freedom of Dublin. It was a highly symbolic moment at the Mansion House, seat of the city's government. Dublin made Mandela an honorary citizen two years ago, the first capital city to do so, but had to wait until now for him to get out of prison and accept the honor. For the Irish, already geared up to give an ecstatic welcome to their national soccer team on its return from the World Cup in Italy, it was a doubly joyous day. ``Is this not the greatest day Ireland has ever seen?'' yelled the master of ceremonies to the crowd outside the Mansion House. ``A double bill _ the Irish team coming home and Nelson Mandela coming to the Mansion House!'' Mandela, seated beside his wife, Winnie, inside the Mansion House, quickly picked up the spirit. ``Congratulations to your wonderful football team,'' he said to applause from the dignitaries. ``I have a hope, please allow me to say so, that they did so magnificently because they knew that in spirit I was amongst them.'' Underdog Ireland, which had never before qualified for the World Cup, got to the quarterfinals before losing to Italy 1-0 Saturday. Mandela immediately called for the maintenance of sanctions, a stance likely to win support here but face opposition in Britain, his next stop. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher wants sanctions lifted in recognition of South African President F. W. de Klerk's reforms, which included releasing Mandela after 27 years in prison. At a European Community summit last week, Ireland, which holds the EC presidency, helped make sure the community's embargo on imports of South African coal, steel and gold coins remains firm. In his speech, Mandela acknowledged de Klerk's reforms, but added: ``Apartheid still remains in place. It is our common duty and responsibility to ensure that apartheid is ended, not tomorrow but now. ... We call for the maintenance of sanctions against South Africa, and solidarity with our struggle.'' At the airport, he ignored a question about his attitude to the Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland and is outlawed in both Ireland and Britain. The IRA's legal political wing, Sinn Fein, strongly supports Mandela. Among the guests at the Mansion House was Paul Hill, one of four Irish people who served more than 14 years in a British prison until a judge freed them this year, accepting that they had been wrongly convicted. Hill said he felt a comradeship with Mandela, who was jailed for plotting the violent overthrow of the white regime. ``It was the affinity of a prisoner with another prisoner who was enduring what I was enduring,'' he told a reporter. Ireland gained its niche in the annals of the anti-apartheid campaign in 1984, when 11 supermarket workers were fired for refusing to handle South African fruit. They picketed the store for nearly three years until they won a court case for unfair dismissal. Mandela was expected to meet with some of the group. The Mansion House, where Ireland's first independent Parliament sat in 1919, symbolizes Irish liberation from centuries of British rule. Others who have been made freemen of Dublin are playwright George Bernard Shaw, Pope John Paul II, and U.S. President John Kennedy. On Monday, Mandela will talk with Prime Minister Charles Haughey and address the Irish Parliament before flying to London.

DOC.TEXT: Actress-singer Pia Zadora and her millionaire husband, Meshulam Riklis, have sold their $4.7 million home here, but they won't be hurting for a place to live. The five-bedroom, 6{-bath house, once owned by jockey Willie Shoemaker, sits on a one-acre piece of property and contains 6,370 square feet. Miss Zadora and Riklis sold it to an unnamed Italian industrialist for $4.7 million, according to Sunday's Los Angeles Times. She and her husband own the site of the legendary Pickfair mansion, where silent film stars Mary Pickford and Douglas Fairbanks Sr. reigned as Hollywood royalty during the 1920s. That mansion has largely been razed to make way for a new home, which will incorporate the fragments of Pickfair that are still standing. Riklis and Miss Zadora also own another house in the Beverly Park section of Beverly Hills and homes in Malibu and New York City.
DOC.NOTE: For release 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Television producers say Warren Beatty is losing some of his mystique as he heavily promotes his role in the movie ``Dick Tracy.'' ``I would imagine the we-got-to-have-him attitude is somewhat diminished,'' Jack Riley, executive producer of ABC's ``Good Morning America,'' said in the July 7 issue of TV Guide. ``But actually, now that he's gotten into it, he's a far better interview than he has been,'' he said. Beatty had stonewalled seasoned interviewer Barbara Walters early on and producers were wary of the once elusive star. ``Donahue'' senior producer Lorri Benson said she was ``pleasantly surprised'' by Beatty's openness when he appeared on the syndicated show. There were no preconditions and no taboo subjects, and Beatty spontaneously agreed to appear on the show a second time, she said. Riley also was leery of scheduling a Beatty interview. He had previously dealt with the star when he was touting his mega-bomb ``Ishtar.'' Beatty taped a segment for ``Good Morning America,'' but later made so many demands that the producers ``dumped the whole thing,'' Riley said. The only constraint in the interview for ``Dick Tracy'' was that 11-year-old co-star Charlie Korsmo be on with him.

Former pop singer Cat Stevens, now known as Yusuf Islam, was barred from entering the country on Sunday by passport officials. Airport officials said Islam, who took his name after converting to the Moslem faith, was turned away as ``an undesirable'' along with his 8-year-old son, Mohammed, after their British Airways jet landed about 4 a.m. They were met on arrival by passport officials and held at the airport for about four hours until the flight returned to London, officials said. One official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Islam and his son accepted the decision quietly. The passport agents were acting on instructions from the Interior Ministry, he said. Islam, a British citizen born Stephen Demetri Georgiou, gave up his singing career a decade ago after his religious conversion. He had a string of hits in the early 1970s, including ``Peace Train'' and ``Morning Has Broken.'' He has been in the headlines recently for supporting the death sentence issued by Iran against author Salman Rushdie.

Prince Charles left the hospital Sunday with his right arm in a cast and sling after breaking it during a polo match. ``You can all go home at last,'' he told reporters and photographers who had staked out the hospital entry since Thursday, when the heir to the British throne suffered two fractures in his right arm. Princess Diana, celebrating her 29th birthday, was by Charles' side as he thanked doctors and nurses at Cirencester Hospital. ``There is still some pain but the swelling is going down in the shoulder and the right arm. He is in good spirits,'' said the prince's spokesman, Dickie Arbiter. The 41-year-old prince, an avid polo player for 25 years, underwent a 45-minute operation to set the two breaks above the elbow of his right arm. Charles was riding his pony, Echo, and playing for his team, Windsor Park, in the semifinal of the Warwickshire Cup against Hildon when he fell. Hildon won the match.

Attorney Fred Thompson was in court and had to miss the opening of ``Days of Thunder'' to see his performance as an auto racing magnate. Thompson also may be too busy this week to see the premier of ``Die Hard 2: Die Harder,'' in which he plays an embattled air traffic controller. Thompson, who makes a hobby of playing no-nonsense characters, was trying to settle a civil matter in Dallas and New Orleans when ``Days of Thunder, starring Tom Cruise, opened. The attorney's specialty is defending people accused of white collar crimes. He has offices in Nashville and Washington. Thompson first received national attention when he was appointed counsel to the Republican minority in the Watergate hearings. He says his acting offers is his own form of entertainment. ``It's a lot of fun,'' said Thompson. ``Some lawyers take sabbaticals, or they devote themselves to intensive hobbies. My `golf' is acting.'' Thompson also played the head of the CIA in ``No Way Out.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Colombians Extradited to U.S. on Drug Charges
DOC.TEXT: Two Colombians wanted on U.S. drug-trafficking charges have been extradited from Colombia and flown to the United States to stand trial, the U.S. Marshals Service said Sunday. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh said in a statement issued by the marshals office that the action demonstrates ``the continued determination of the Colombian government to battle the Colombian drug cartel'' and to ``bring these drug dealing suspects to justice.'' The two were identified as Luis Carbacas, 60, charged with leading a drug ring in North Carolina, and Rafael Juliao, 42, charged with cocaine distribution in New York City. They are among 17 people extradited from Colombia since the government of Colombian President Virgilio Barco began its drive against the narcotics cartel last August. Carbacas and Juliao were turned over to the marshals service in Bogota on Saturday evening and were flown to the United States early Sunday morning. Carbacas was among 39 people indicted in 1985 on charges that included conspiracy to possess and distribute 2 million methaqualone tablets and more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana. He was accused with engaging in a continuing criminal enterprise as a ring organizer, a violation of the so-called drug kingpin law. He is to stand trial in North Carolina. Juliao, who is being held for arraignment in Manhattan, is charged with distributing 3 kilograms (about 6.6 pounds) of cocaine and conspiring to distribute 5 kilograms of cocaine.

DOC.HEAD: Annual Hajj Peaks In Most Peaceful Year Since 1986
DOC.TEXT: Two million Moslems stood in prayer Sunday on Arafat, the mount overlooking Mecca where the Prophet Mohammed delivered his last sermon 14 centuries ago, as the annual Moslem pilgrimage reached its high point. For the first time since 1986, the Moslem pilgrimage, called the hajj, has been free from terrorist attacks. Only a small fire at Mina, the tent city five miles from Arafat, marred an otherwise calm pilgrimage season. Witnesses said that on their descent from Arafat they spotted smoke from a distance. One said they were told it was at Mina, but it did not appear to be a large blaze. Fire can be a danger during the hajj because some pilgrims bring kerosene stoves to cook in the tents. Terrorism blamed on Iranian or Shiite Moslems has occurred in the past three years. The worst incident was in 1987, when Iranians clashed with security forces, leading to the death of more than 400 pilgrims. The year before, the Saudis confiscated large quantities of explosives from members of the Iranian contingent. The Saudis have since set a quota of 1,000 per million of population for each Islamic nation. Angered by the quotas, the Iranians have boycotted the hajj since 1988. Last year, some small bombs went off during the hajj, killing one pilgrim and injuring 16. The Saudis tried and convicted Kuwaiti Shiite Moslems and beheaded 16 of them. Saudi authorities this year reported a growing number of pilgrims for the hajj. The Saudis said 827,236 pilgrims arrived from around the world, about 52,000 more than last year and some 30,000 more than 1988. They were joined by about half a million pilgrims from Saudi Arabia and its large expatriate community. An additional half million people were needed for servicing tasks. The deputy governor of Mecca region, Prince Saud ibn Abdul-Mohsen, who is also deputy chairman of the Central Hajj Committee, said the ascent of pilgrims by car and foot over the 5.5-mile route from Mina to Arafat was ``perfectly organized and the flow of traffic was very smooth.'' He said a few cases of heat fatigue were reported, but were not serious. Temperatures reached 111 degrees. He said the pilgrims used umbrellas and awnings for shade, and that 8.7 million flasks of iced water were distributed, a pet project of the Saudi monarch, King Fahd. The stand at Arafat is considered the peak of the rituals, and anyone who misses it will not be considered to have performed hajj. The day is spent reading the Koran, the Moslem holy book, and praying. Dawn prayers Monday mark the start of the three-day Eid al-Adha or Feast of Sacrifice, when sheep are slaughtered by the pilgrims and Moslems everywhere to commemorate prophet Abraham's offering of his son to God. Abraham is revered by Moslems as well as by Jews and Christians. The hajj is a pillar of the Islamic faith. Moslems who are healthy and can afford it are required to perform the hajj at least once in their lifetime.

DOC.HEAD: Cianci: Providence Mayor, Felon, Talk Show Host, And Now Mayor Again?
DOC.TEXT: Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. _ convicted felon, media personality, former mayor _ is trying to become mayor again. And if the 49-year-old independent candidate wins in November, it will be a journey Cianci says will make him a better leader. ``A lot of people say they didn't like me as mayor but they liked me on the radio,'' Cianci said. ``The radio station made me listen and made me aware that there were other points of view. ``It's kept me sharp and it's kept me current.'' Elected in 1974, he was forced out of office 10 years later after he attacked his estranged wife's lover with a fireplace log, an ashtray and a lit cigarette. He pleaded no contest to two assault charges, and in April 1984 he received a five-year suspended sentence and probation. After his ouster, Cianci wanted to run in the special mayoral election and complete his four-year term in the state's largest city with 160,000 residents. But the state Supreme Court ruled that his conviction barred him from doing so. The ruling applied only to the special election and does not prevent Cianci from running today. In March 1985, Cianci took up a career as a radio commentator with WHJJ-AM. His three-hour afternoon talk show, a combination interview and call-in show, was the state's most popular talk show until he gave it up to run again. He also did political commentary for two TV stations. Rhode Island political junkies discussed a Cianci return for months. Even President Bush joined in, asking a Providence journalist in March: ``How about Buddy Cianci? ... Talk about a guy who liked to mix it up!'' Cianci maintains he didn't make a final decision until Wednesday, the day he announced his bid on the air. As proof, he points to his lack of money and staff. On the other hand, he also notes that dollars are not vital to him at this early stage _ ``I certainly don't need to get my name known.'' Darrell West of Brown University's Public Opinion Center said that a crowded ballot could work to Cianci's advantage. Besides Cianci, there's another independent in the race, plus Democratic and Republican candidates to be chosen during primaries in September. ``It could be a good race from Buddy's point of view,'' West said. ``If there's a four-person race, that probably means 35 to 40 percent is going to win. ``It's not as if Buddy has to convince the majority to become mayor. A lot of people accept that he's got 20 to 25 percent, so he only needs another 15 percent.'' Cianci, who puts his core of supporters at 30 percent, managed to upstage both state political parties with his announcement. He filed his papers the day of the Democratic and Republican conventions, effectively stealing their thunder in the next day's newspapers and broadcasts. State Rep. Paul Jabour, who's among the five Democrats vying for mayor, pooh-poohed Cianci's candidacy, saying: ``A voter is one thing, and a fan club is another.'' But state Rep. Frank Fiorenzano opined: ``If it wasn't for the problems he got himself into, there's probably nothing he could not have obtained. ... I wish I knew what it was. I would like to get it and bottle it and give it to myself.'' State Sen. Victoria Lederberg, another mayoral hopeful, suggested a new slogan for her campaign: ``Let's keep Buddy on the air.'' Still, she said he would definitely liven things up. ``I tend to get bored with the race,'' she said. ``With Buddy in the race, I'm not bored.'' Cianci's not bored, either. He said his past ordeals and the six years of public penance have made him more willing to be held accountable. ``I'd probably be the only officeholder in the state under the most public scrutiny, and I welcome that. It doesn't bother me,'' he said. ``The city of Providence and the people of Providence owe me nothing. I owe them everything.''

DOC.HEAD: Missing Infant Found Safe In Missouri; Teen-Ager In Custody
DOC.TEXT: An infant taken from a hospital's nursery more than a week ago was back in her parents' arms Sunday, the result of an anonymous telephone tip to police. ``She's gained a pound since she's been gone and she's healthy and eats all the time,'' Teresa Morse, 27, said after arriving back in Oklahoma City with her nearly 2-week-old daughter, Whitney. ``I'm just going to take her home and try on all the clothes she's got, and go shopping and go out somewhere instead of staying home all the time.'' The infant, abducted June 20 when she was 2 days old, was found safe in Butler, Mo. Her parents flew there to get their first-born child soon after police and FBI agents told them she had been found. Police Chief Dave McBride said 18-year-old Heather Brewster of Butler was arrested and faces federal kidnapping charges. Max Geiman, FBI spokesman in Kansas City, said Ms. Brewster was being held as a federal prisoner in the Clay County jail. Formal charges will be filed Monday, he said. McBride said Ms. Brewster, who is single, had apparently suffered a miscarriage and had carried on the pretense of being pregnant. McBride said that even though she lives more than 200 miles away, the woman was familiar with the Oklahoma City area, adding: ``She came here with the intent of taking a baby back.'' Oklahoma City police Maj. Bob Taylor said 13 infants were abducted in similar cases nationwide last year, and all were found. A woman dressed in hospital scrubs went into the nursery at Deaconess Hospital late June 20 and told nurses she was there to check out the baby to take it to the infant's parents. Hospital officials called police a couple of hours later after discovering the baby was gone. The break in the case came late Friday night when someone from Missouri called police with ``good, specific information,'' McBride said. He said he could not go into specifics because that would reveal the identity of the caller, who was promised anonymity. Bates County Sheriff Leonard Hough questioned Ms. Brewster late Saturday and notified FBI agents after the woman was unable to answer some questions, McBride said. The baby was positively identified early Sunday. Bob Ricks, special agent in charge of the FBI in Oklahoma, said the infant's footprints were sent by facsimile machine to Butler and a fingerprint expert was sent to check the child. ``On the airplane I thought `I'm over it now. I'm just over it,' '' Mrs. Morse said. ``There's no pain ... (but) it'll probably take me a while to trust again without being with her all the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Plan to Return Delights Supporters
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela saluted Californians for taking economic sanctions against South Africa and pledged to help American Indians when he returns in October. Mandela announced Saturday he would return to the United States to visit Indian reservations and ``exchange views as to what I can do to help them in their struggle.'' ``The Indian people have written to me and explained their problems, and it is but natural that I should respond to that by seeing them as I proposed to do,'' Mandela said at a brief news conference before he left Oakland, finishing his 11-day whirlwind trip through the United States. The announcement was greeted with enthusiasm by the American Indians, including Rep. Ben Nighthorse-Campbell, the only American Indian in Congress. Indians and South African blacks ``face some similar background problems,'' said the Colorado Democrat. ``The difference I think is that nobody is intentionally preventing Indians from becoming part of the Legislature,'' he said. ``In South Africa, they virtually lock black people out of running from office.'' Hundreds of Mandela's supporters were disappointed when he cut short by a day his visit to Oakland in order to make an appointment with Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughy. ``I'm not mad, but it is dismaying to get so close just to be disappointed,'' said Ethelou Talbert of Oakland. Mandela and his wife, Winnie, had to cancel a reception for Winnie; a $100-a-plate dinner; and a $2,500-per-couple reception. The events went ahead and organizer Sandre Swanson said she did not expect to make many refunds. ``People were giving for the cause to free South Africa, not just to see Nelson and Winnie Mandela,'' Swanson said. Mandela, 71, deputy president of the African National Congress, was freed in February after 27 years in a South African prison for plotting sabotage to overthrow the nation's white government. Mandela's representatives said they considered canceling the entire Oakland visit, but Rep. Ron Dellums, who represents Oakland in Congress, intervened to save Mandela's sold-out speech before a crowd of 58,000 at the Oakland-Alameda County Coliseum. During his 20-minute Coliseum speech, Mandela hailed Californians for their role in the movement to persuade institutions to sell off stock in companies doing business in South Africa. ``We salute the state of California for having such a powerful political stance on divestment,'' he said, praising students at the University of California for pressuring officials to divest. ``We salute the longshoremen for refusing to unload the ship (with South African cargo) in 1984.'' Supporters waved black, green and gold ANC flags, beat on drums and stood to roar their support for the black South African hero of the anti-apartheid movement. ``We are at a true historical junction. We cannot turn back,'' said Mandela, thrusting his trademark clenched fist in the air. ``We will not turn back.'' Oakland was the final stop on the grueling eight-city fund-raising tour of the United States, one of 14 countries on a round-the-world trip. Although final fund-raising figures will not be available until next week, Mandela said the U.S. visit ``has succeeded beyond our wildest dreams.'' Total tour estimates range from $3 million to $7 million, according to organizers. More than $900,000 was raised at Oakland events, according to Mark Mosher of the Osborn Group, the public relations company handling media coverage of the visit. But that figure does not include informal hat-passing and other spontaneous donations, he said. For Mandela, the trip bolstered more than the ANC bankroll. ``I feel like an old battery that has been recharged,'' he said upon his arrival at Oakland International Airport.

DOC.HEAD: Man Has Found Way to Enjoy Two Hobbies: Cycling and Ham Radio
DOC.TEXT: Herb Viegas is a cycling ham _ ham radio operator, that is. The 69-year-old Viegas cycles long distances and talks to people even farther away at the same time with the ham radio he installed on his bicycle. He said he surprises and confuses some of those he reaches as he rides along and sends out his greeting: ``Hello, this is WJ5, bicycle mobile.'' With his bicycle radio, he has talked to people as far away as New York and Minnesota. ``I put out a pretty good signal, and the guys hear me, and I get a pile of them wanting to talk to me,'' Viegas said. Shortly after retiring from LTV Corp. about 10 years ago, Viegas took up cycling. He also began tinkering in his workshop at home. ``I decided that I didn't want to spend all of my time in there,'' he said. ``So I thought that I would try to rig a ham radio for my bike.'' Viegas had to figure out what kind of regulator to use for the voltage provided by a generator on the back tire of his 12-speed. But once he did, he began beaming out his signal. ``I rode 4,000 miles last year,'' Viegas said. ``When I'm riding, I'll talk to people and tell them that I am riding a bike and can't write their names. I ask them to send me a card.'' Plenty of cooperative hams have done just that. Cards line a wall in Viegas' home from points in the world that he has reached. One from Fulton, N.Y., reads: ``Herb, you are my first bicycle mobile contact. You have a great signal and you'd never know that you were on a bike.''

DOC.HEAD: Zoning Violation Fells Anti-Crime Billboard
DOC.TEXT: A billboard featuring McGruff the crime-fighting dog had to come down last week. It was illegal. The billboard was removed Thursday, one day after Kalamazoo officials said it violated the city zoning ordinance. Adams Outdoor Advertising Co. also failed to obtain a permit before erecting the billboard two weeks earlier, city officials said. The billboard featured not only McGruff but a telephone number allowing anonymous callers to report information about suspected drug dealers. It was sponsored by a neighborhood business association. Deputy City Manager James Perkins said he hoped Adams would display the billboard _ legally _ elsewhere. But Adams General Manager Michael Romoser said McGruff's canine countenance wouldn't appear on other company billboards. ``I don't anticipate how it could,'' he said Thursday. ``It appears all of these good intentions have been for naught.''

DOC.HEAD: President-Elect Fujimori Arrives in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Fujimori, president-elect of Peru, hoped to revive Japanese econmic aid to his country and travel to his parents' birthplace during a visit that began Sunday night. Fujimori is to have an audience Monday with Emperor Akihito at the Imperial Palace and meet with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. In talks with Kaifu, Fujimori is expected to ask Japan to resume credits and extend technological aid to help Peru recover from economic depression. ``I wish to re-establish the flowering cooperation with this great country,'' he said before leaving for Japan. Fujimori, an agronomist, was a political unknown before he defeated celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in Peru's June 10 presidential runoff. He played up his Japanese heritage during the campaign, even posing dressed as a samurai warrior for news photographers. Fujimori's Japanese ancestry has raised hopes the Peru will have greater access to Japanese aid. Peru was the largest recipient of Japanese aid in Latin America in cumulative until 1988 but dropped to fourth-largest after it defaulted on payments and Japan cut off its credits. Japanese officials have said Japan is willing to help after hearing Fujimori's plans for dealing with Peru's problems. The Foreign Ministry says Peru owes Japan about $1 billion in government and private credits. Japan had extended credits totaling $359 million since 1971. The last was in 1983 _ a credit of $31.3 million for fishing port construction, the ministry said. During his five-day visit, Fujimori is to confer with Japanese business leaders before leaving Wednesday for Kumamoto, from where his parents emigrated to Peru in 1934. Kumamoto is on Japan's southernmost main island of Kyushu. Fujimori leaves Japan Thursday for home. He is to be inaugurated July 28 for a five-year term.

DOC.HEAD: China Launches Largest-Ever Census
DOC.TEXT: China on Sunday launched its largest census ever, mobilizing 7 million people to count the world's most populous nation. For the next 10 days, census takers throughout the country _ from the crowded coastal cities to its desolate western regions _ will be knocking on doors to get the latest count of China's estimated 1.1 billion people. Census-takers arrived at 9 a.m. at Zhongnanhai, the red-walled compound housing Communist Party headquarters and homes of the top leaders, the evening TV news reported. The report showed two young census workers interviewing Communist Party General Secretary Jiang Zemin and Premier Li Peng, running through the standard questions of name, age and address, even though in their cases the answers are common knowledge. Census workers also arrived early at the homes of ordinary citizens. ``They didn't stay very long _ just asked their questions and left,'' said a 50-year-old worker from central Beijing who gave only her surname, Kang. ``This was actually their last visit, not their first. They've come several times already getting ready for the census.'' Since spring, officials have been making checks to confirm that household registrations are up to date. Census workers have also staged practice runs, visiting families and filling out questionnaires. To ensure the accuracy of the head count, China is sending its census takers door-to-door for the first time. Previously, residents were asked to visit census stations for the three censuses conducted since the Communists came to power in 1949. Publicity for the census has been ubiquitous since the spring. Billboards and banners remind citizens that a successful census requires their cooperation, and newspaper editorials explain why it's necessary to count the nation's people. For the past two months, government notices posted on a low green fence in Kang's neighborhood have kept residents informed of the census proceedings. ``It's a very necessary task,'' said another resident, who did not give his name. ``It's just like a family _ how can you take care of your family if you don't even know how many of you there are and what everyone's doing?'' Kang and others noted that the 21-item questionnaire was more detailed than that of the previous census in 1982. Most, however, said they didn't mind answering questions about each family member's name, age, education level and occupation as well as about household features and child-bearing conditions for women. But the same questions strike fear in the hearts of China 20 million-strong floating population, who have moved to cities without permission, and among those who have had children in violation of China's strict family planning policy. In Beijing, census workers headed out Saturday evening to count the floating population, many of whom work during the day and return home late, said Zhu Yilin, head of the municipal census office. Initial results of the census will be published in October, but it will take nearly two years to process the data they collect.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Continues Deliberations on Imelda Marcos
DOC.TEXT: Jurors considering racketeering and fraud charges against former Philippine first lady Imelda Marcos reviewed more testimony Sunday in their fourth day of deliberations. The jurors resumed their discussions in the early afternoon after some members attended church services. Mrs. Marcos, whose 61st birthday is Monday, is charged with racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. She is accused of helping her late husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, buy jewelry, artworks and four Manhattan buildings with $222 million allegedly looted from their homeland's treasury. The jurors also are deliberating mail fraud and obstruction of justice charges against her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. Khashoggi, 54, is accused of allegedly helping the Marcoses hide ownership of the buildings after a U.S. court order froze their assets. On Sunday, the panel reheard testimony about one of the underlying racketeering acts, which claims Mrs. Marcos helped to fraudulently obtain millions of dollars in loans to finance the four properties. The jury, which is sequestered, began deliberations Thursday afternoon. The three-month trial in U.S. District Court included testimony from 95 prosecution witnesses. The defense called no witnesses. If convicted, Mrs. Marcos faces up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines. Khashoggi could draw a sentence of 10 years and a $500,000 fine. Marcos, who was ousted from power in February 1986, was originally charged along with his wife but was found too ill to stand trial. He died in September.

DOC.HEAD: Voyager Co-Pilot Jeana Yeager Has Rough Landing In Desert Air Race
DOC.TEXT: Jeana Yeager, who made history in the non-stop round-the-world flight of the Voyager in 1986, escaped injury Sunday after an experimental plane she was co-piloting caught fire and crashed during an emergency landing. Elko County Sheriff's Deputy James Neff said Yeager and pilot Shirland K. Dickey were about four miles from the airport the engine caught fire and smoke was detected in the cockpit. He said the engine quit while the plane was still a half-mile out and Yeager and Dickey made a dead stick landing, a landing made without any power. On touching down, the plane left the runway and its landing gear collapsed, he said, but the 38-year-old Yeager of Nipomo, Calif., and Dickey, 48, of Chandler, Ariz., walked away. Neff said an unidentified Jackpot volunteer firefighter suffered minor smoke inhalation while trying to douse a fire in the wreckage. The deputy said the pair were flying an experimental propeller-driven plane in the 8th Annual International E-Z Air Show and were on the final approach of a 120-mile race between Jackpot and Wells, Nev. Yeager and pilot Dick Rutan set aviation history in December 1986 when they flew the Voyager in a nine-day unrefueled circumnavigation of the globe.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli-Arab Poet Released From House Arrest
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli Arab poet charged with identifying with a terrorist organization was released from house arrest Sunday. Shafik Habib, a 49-year-old accountant known for his ``political poetry,'' was placed under house arrest in mid-June after police said his poems could incite violence. Publication of Habib's poems was also banned. On June 19, Habib was charged with identifying with an unspecified terrorist group. No trial date was set. The move sparked protests by Arab legislators and the Palestinian Israeli Writers' Union. Arab intellectuals saying they feared it could signal a police crackdown on Israeli Arab nationalists. On Friday, Habib appealed the house arrest, saying it restricted his freedom as an individual and freedom of movement, and harmed his income. Haifa's District Court Judge Micha Lindenstrauss on Sunday upheld Habib's appeal and ordered the poet released. ``It is enough that the (military) censor has banned publication of the poems. Preventing publication is a reasonable solution to guard public safety,'' Lindenstrauss said in his decision. Police officials say Habib's poems call for violence against Jews and support the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: Ruby Youngs, White House Switchboard Operator, Dies at 82
DOC.TEXT: Ruby O. Youngs, who served as a White House switchboard operator under five presidents, has died at a Franklin County retirement home. She was 82. Ms. Youngs, who died Friday, worked as a White House operator for more than 20 years, spanning the administrations of Presidents Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon. She retired just before the Watergate scandal ended the Nixon presidency in 1974. Mildred Campbell, who worked with Ms. Youngs at the White House, said she was a steadying influence on younger operators. ``She was very intelligent. I thought she was the best,'' Ms. Campbell said. Ms. Youngs also served as a switchboard operator for former American Motion Picture Association chief Jack Valenti. Ms. Youngs moved to Roanoke in the 1970s to live near her son, who has since died.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bullfighter, Romantically Linked To Ava Gardner, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Mario Cabre, a former Spanish bullfighter and actor who in the 1950s was romantically linked to the late actress Ava Gardner, died in a Barcelona clinic of a heart ailment Sunday, doctors said. He was 75. Cabre was widely known in Spain, not only as a bullfighter, but also for his romance with Gardner during the film ``Pandora and the wandering Dutchman,'' which they made together in the Spanish Costa Brava. After retiring from the bullring in 1960 following a 17-year career, he played leading roles in a number of Spanish films and plays. Cabre also wrote several books of poetry.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki Announces Plans To Talk With Walesa
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki offered Sunday to meet this week with Lech Walesa to ease the bitter political war that has torn the Solidarity movement. An aid to Walesa said the Solidarity chairman was aware of the offer and that arrangements for the meeting would probably be announced soon. Mazowiecki's peace gesture came at a meeting of local Solidarity Citizens Committees called by his backers in the conflict. Walesa has accused his former ally of moving too slowly to implement political and economic reforms. Members of Citizens Committees from around the country met Saturday with Walesa and then Sunday with Mazowiecki to discuss what direction the Solidarity union movement should take. Mazowiecki's backers failed to win enough support to create a nationwide federation of Citizens Committees behind the government. Instead, the issue was postponed until a conference July 21. Sunday's meeting passed a resolution urging the Solidarity leader and Mazowiecki to cooperate. Taking the floor earlier, Mazowiecki told the local activists meeting in the parliament building that he was always willing to talk with Walesa even though he had been attacked by him. He said he would call Walesa on condition that the conversation would be conducted as a ``full partnership'' and not as Mazowiecki ``paying a serf's homage.'' ``I think that certain issues should be toned down,'' Mazowiecki said. ``I am proposing to Mr. Walesa to talk this coming week.'' Mazowiecki said they should talk ``not to remove all differences between us, because that would not be true, but to talk so that disputes and battles proceed in a way that does not destroy the common good of Poland and Solidarity's legacy.'' Asked later, he declined to elaborate on specific topics for discussion. Walesa aide Krzysztof Pusz, reached at home in Gdansk, said Walesa was aware of Mazowiecki's proposal. ``I think the details should be worked out this week,'' Pusz said. The Walesa and Mazowiecki factions were competing for the allegiance of the grass roots during the weekend meetings, and the fight seemed to end in a draw. Delegates were not enthusiastic by the call from the Mazowiecki faction for creating a national federation that would act as a base of support for the government. But in a straw poll Sunday, they also rejected Walesa's proposal that the Citizens Committees be opened to members of other political groups. The question of the committees' role is important because they constitute easily the country's strongest political force. In last year's parliamentary elections and last month's local elections, virtually all candidates endorsed by the Solidarity Citizens Committees won. Walesa argues that the local committees should admit supporters of other budding political parties and become forums for discussing public issues. He also says they should be free to criticize the government. Otherwise, he said, Solidarity could itself become a monopoly and eventually be taken over by people with dictatorial tendencies. Supporters of Mazowiecki accuse Walesa of demagoguery. They want the local committees to band together to create a national federation to defend Mazowiecki's government, which is carrying out difficult economic reforms. The 9-month-old government has introduced radical economic reforms. But it has taken a gradual approach to dismantling the old Communist power structure and dismissing Communist holdovers, arguing the alternative would be witch hunts and chaos. The prime minister told the meeting Sunday that there is need for ``political support for this cause taking place in Poland.'' ``The question is should we slacken and withdraw,'' he said, ``or go further, knowing it will be difficult.'' At a meeting June 24 of ranking Solidarity members, 63 of Walesa's oldest advisers broke ranks, accusing him of trying to make the Citizens Committees into a tool of his widely expected campaign for president.

DOC.HEAD: Trump's Real Work Is 'Round The Corner: If And What to Sell
DOC.TEXT: The hard work starts for Donald Trump once the bankers finish his $65 million bailout plan. The developer will have to restructure his empire and probably sell some of his vast holdings to raise cash. The banks hope that by deferring about $800 million of his $2 billion bank debt for up to five years, Trump will gain time to sell his assets in an orderly way. ``The banks believe the assets he possesses are valuable enough to be sold over time at respectable prices and are certainly enough to keep his operation viable,'' said a source close to the negotiations. A rush sale would have meant low prices that would have kept Trump from meeting his debt obligations to the banks, the source added. As it is, the value of his assets has been depressed by the sagging real estate market and the increasingly stagnant Atlantic City gambling market. The developer's properties include Trump Tower, whose marble shopping arcade has become a big tourist attraction, the ritzy Plaza Hotel, the Trump Shuttle with its fleet of 17 aircraft, and casinos in Atlantic City. Trump will have to sell some of his assets to raise cash ``unless ... the Atlantic City operations begin to support (his) debt record and that's the wild card,'' said Edward S. Gordon, president and chief executive officer of the commercial real estate firm bearing his name. Bankers hope the paperwork for their $65 million loan to Trump will be completed within 30 days. About 70 banks on Tuesday lent Trump $20 million immediately so he could meet a midnight deadline on a $43 million payment on bonds backing one of his casinos. In a statement Tuesday, Trump said the bailout deal ``reflects and confirms the inherent long-term value of our assets including Trump Tower, the Plaza Hotel, the Atlantic City hotels and the Trump Shuttle.'' Trump has has discussed selling his East Coast air service, and the Trump Princess, the 282-foot yacht he bought for $30 million. Business Week reported last month that he is also listening to offers for Trump Castle, his worst-performing casino, and, according to real estate sources, thinking about selling the Plaza Hotel _ which Trump likes to call it ``the ultimate trophy in the world.'' Last week the Daily News in New York quoted an unidentified banker close to the Trump negotiations as saying that Trump's share in Alexander's department stores would probably be among the first assets he would sell. Trump paid nearly $70 million for a 27 percent stake in the retailing company and planned to develop its real estate holdings into huge commercial and retailing centers. Also among his assets is Trump City _ 76 acres of undeveloped land on Manhattan's West Side that was the site of an unused rail yard. He paid about $100 million in 1985 and wants to build the world's tallest building, luxury apartments and a shopping mall there. The plan has been presented to the city Planning Commission but is not yet in the often lengthy land use approval process. It has been held up, in part, by community activists who oppose the project for environmental reasons. Forbes magazine says Trump values the property at $650 million, though Forbes puts its worth at $200 million and Business Week says it would sell for only $160 million.

DOC.HEAD: NOW Considers Third Political Party
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS lead to CORRECT name of organization; Fixes TYPO in 5th graf, ```Washington is...
DOC.TEXT: Proposals to form an alternative to the ``white male-dominated'' Republican and Democratic parties generated intense interest at a three-day meeting of the National Organization for Women that ended Sunday. Participants at the annual NOW convention listened to suggestions for a political party to represent feminists, pro-choice advocates, gays, minorities, ecologists and those opposed to nuclear power and weapons. ``Our friends and our allies called us `suicidal,' and `naive,''' when the third-party idea surfaced at last year's convention, NOW Vice President Patricia Ireland said Saturday. ``But are we naive?'' ``Isn't it time, with a Congress that's 95 percent male, 95 percent white _ with only two `out' gay males, and no `out' gay females. Isn't it time for a representative democracy?'' Ireland asked to shouts of approval. ``Washington is a company town and we just threatened the company,'' she said. West German Parliament member Petra Kelly, who helped form the anti-nuclear Green Party in her country in 1979, urged a crowd of about 2,400 NOW members Saturday to think about becoming an ``alternative political force.'' ``If not now, when are you going to do it? The time has come,'' Kelly said, criticizing the Democratic and Republican parties as too similar. The established parties protect the interests of the white, male-dominated bureaucracy, she said. ``What a legacy it is they have left us: Bhopal, Chernobyl, Love Canal, global warming,'' she said. NOW President Molly Yard tried to remind the group that a third party was only one of several election reform ideas being studied by the organization. ``We haven't come to the conclusion that we should have a third party,'' said Yard. ``Yes we have!'' delegates roared back. NOW's Commission on Democracy in the Twenty-First Century is scheduled to make its recommendations for political change at the NOW convention next summer in New York City. Also Saturday, about 500 conference participants staged an abortion rights rally at Union Square, and listened to speeches by politicians campaigning against two anti-abortion incumbents. ``We are going to do it this year because our message is right and Jesse Helms is wrong and divisive,'' said Harvey Gantt, a North Carolina Democrat trying to unseat Helms. Pennsylvania Republican gubernatorial candidate Barbara Hafer said she trusted ``women in Pennsylvania to make important choices for themselves.'' About 100 anti-abortion protesters gathered near the rally, carrying signs that read: ``NOW does not represent me'' and ``Not NOW, not ever.'' Yard announced a possible boycott against a major European chemical company, Roussel Uclaf, if it does not market its abortion pill, RU-486, in the United States. NOW representatives have gathered 70,000 petition signatures to pressure the company into marketing the drug, now sold only in France. The National Right to Life Committee has threatened to prevent manufacture or sale of the drug in the United States by boycotting pharmaceutical companies. The American Medical Association's House of Delegates last week voted to endorse testing and possible use of RU-486 in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Government Troops Report Capture of Tamil Rebel Base
DOC.TEXT: Government troops broke through a cordon of bunkers and overran a strategic Tamil Tiger base on the northwestern coast, killing 25 guerrillas, military officials said Sunday. One soldier was killed and 25 wounded in Saturday's operation, the officials said on condition of anonymity. The loss of the base in the village of Marichchukkaddi, 115 miles north of Colombo, is a major blow to the rebels, officials said. They said it was hidden in dense forest and close to the sea, making it an ideal point for transporting men and weapons. Government troops are still battling for control of the northern Jaffna peninsula, where the rebels have besieged a government garrison since the latest round of fighting began June 11. Since mounting a counteroffensive, government troops claim to have captured most of this island nation's eastern districts, which have large Tamil populations, forcing the rebels into the jungles and swamps. In the eastern port city of Batticaloa, 135 miles east of Colombo, Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne visited troops on Sunday. He told them the battle was not against the Tamil population, the military officials said. Wijeratne also urged government officials to go into every Tamil home on a ``win-their-hearts-and-mind campaign,'' the officials said. Since the city was recaptured June 18, Tamil residents have expressed fears that the mostly Sinhalese troops would launch reprisals against them. During the past four days, government troops captured 75 Tiger rebels who had mingled with the civilian population after Batticaloa was recaptured, said local residents, requesting anonymity. They said the rebels were identified by members of rival Tamil groups from among more than 2,000 young Tamils rounded up by the soldiers. On Saturday, police raided the homes of 10 Tamil parliament members in Colombo, the capital, to disarm them and their bodyguards, a military official said Sunday. The official said 35 guns and 20,000 round of ammunition were captured in the raids on homes of deputies from the Eelam Revolutionary Organization of Students, whose 13 members in the 221-seat parliament support the Tiger rebels. The rebels have waged a seven-year insurgency to establish an independent Tamil homeland in the north and east of this island nation. They claim the Tamil minority is discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese in jobs and education. Sinhalese comprise 75 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and control the government and the military. Tamils make up 18 percent of the population. The latest fighting between Tamil Tigers and government forces erupted June 11 after a Tamil man complained to the rebels that he had been manhandled by Sinhalese police in Batticaloa. At least 1,820 people have died in the fighting.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister: Military Must Help Solve Housing Crisis
DOC.TEXT: The defense minister said Sunday that the military must help build housing for the tens of thousands of soldiers and their families returning from service in the formerly Communist countries of the Warsaw Pact. Dmitri T. Yazov told the government newspaper Izvestia that the housing crisis facing returning troops was the ``issue of issues'' confronting the Soviet military. More than 25,000 soldiers and their families are on their way back to the Soviet Union from neighboring Czechoslovakia and Hungary, Yazov told Izvestia. Another 173,600 were already waiting in dormitories and hotels for permanent housing, he said. The Soviet military, along with local government councils, should ``above all, sharply increase the pace and volume of private construction'' of new housing to ease the crunch, he said. Yazov said that 440,000 apartments are scheduled to be built within the next five years. Already this year, 43,000 troops and their dependents have returned from Czechoslovakia, Poland and Hungary, adding to the 27,000 withdrawn from East Germany and Hungary. The overthrow of Communist rule in all of the East bloc countries except Bulgaria has accelerated plans announced two years ago by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to bring back more than 500,000 troops from Eastern Europe. Demands by Hungary and Czechoslovakia that the withdrawal of all 120,000 Soviet troops from their territory be completed by mid-1991 have accelerated the pullout, and the pressure to find housing. For strategic reasons, most of the troops are being stationed in the Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia, the Slavic republics on the Soviet Union's western border. There is already a critical housing shortage in some areas of Byelorussia because of the need to relocate thousands of people whose land was irradiated in the 1986 Chernobyl nuclear disaster. In addition, some local groups apparently are not happy about the prospect of becoming garrison towns. Yazov said that informal groups in Ivano-Frankovsk in the southwestern corner of the Ukraine, near the border with Romania, had blocked construction of military housing. ``It is shameful to hear such things as that,'' Yazov told the newspaper. The United States and Soviet Union have both agreed to trim their forces in Central Europe to 195,000 each, except for 30,000 U.S. troops to be left in Britain and southern Europe. The United States has about 310,000 troops in Europe, including 250,000 in Germany. The Soviet Union has about 380,000 troops in East Germany and Moscow is pressing West Germany to help finance housing construction once the troops are pulled out. Bonn has expressed a willingness to help, and the issue is likely to be discussed when Chancellor Helmut Kohl vi sits Moscow July 15-16.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Scattered Across Eastern United States
DOC.TEXT: Strong thunderstorms were scattered across the eastern United States from Pennsylvania to Alabama on Sunday, and it was also raining in the Dakotas. Scattered showers and thunderstorms were reported over eastern South Dakota and southeastern North Dakota, with a few showers and thunderstorms over Florida and south-central Texas as well. Showers and thunderstorms produced an inch of rain at Key West, Fla., curing the six-hour period ending at 2 p.m. EDT, and half an inch of rain at Apalachicola. Sunny and dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation. Hot weather that has brought 100-degree temperatures to the Desert Southwest as well as Colorado, Wyoming, Idaho and Montana the past week also began to affect parts of Alaska. Fairbanks reported a record high of 86 degrees Saturday, with predicted highs of 90 degrees Sunday. Temperatures were above 90 degrees Sunday afternoon across much of the area from the southern Atlantic Coast to the high Plains, with readings above 100 degrees in Kansas, Colorado and Nebraska. Pleasantly mild temperatures prevailed in the upper Mississippi Valley, the Great Lakes and the Northeast, with readings mostly in the 70s. Afternoon temperatures were in the 60s from the lower Great Lakes to New England. Readings were soaring into the upper 80s and 90s as far north as Idaho and Montana, and over 100 in the Southwest. At noon Phoenix reported 108 degrees. Morning lows were generally in the 50s and 60s in the Great Basin and across the northern half of the country, with lows in the 40s in Idaho, Montana and Colorado. The low for the nation Sunday morning was 44 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Thunderstorms produced locally heavy rain in the Ohio Valley and the middle Atlantic Coast early Sunday. Flooding was reported in Valley Head, W. Va., drenched with 2 inches of rain. At least sixteen Western cities reporting record highs on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Father of Flight 103 Victim Smuggled Fake Bomb Aboard Flight
DOC.TEXT: A man whose daughter died in the December 1988 bombing of Pam Am Flight 103 said Sunday he smuggled a fake bomb past security officials at Heathrow airport and checked it aboard a flight to the United States. In an interview with British Broadcasting Corp. radio, Dr. Jim Swire said he took the bomb aboard an airliner several weeks ago, but declined to name the airline. Swire said the device was made to resemble the bomb that exploded on the flight, killing 270 people, including his daughter Flora. The bomb is believed to have had a barometric trigger designed to detonate at a specific altitude. The Boeing 747, bound for New York, was at more than 30,000 feet over the town of Lockerbie, Scotland, when it disintegrated. Swire said his device was packed inside a radio-cassette recorder, but used marzipan icing instead of semtex plastic explosives. ``We actually took marzipan icing because that's pliable and feels like semtex...and looks similar on X-ray,'' he said. ``In addition, it had a dummy detonator which would have shown up on X-ray, an extra printed circuit board, extra batteries, pressure transducer and so on, all wired up in a form that would have worked if the marzipan had been replaced with semtex,'' Swire said. ``Our flight was selected for what they call special security, and our cases were opened and searched in front of us. The radio-cassette recorder was picked up, and I was asked whether I had taken the batteries out, and I correctly replied, `yes, I had taken the batteries out.' It was then replaced in the suitcase and is now in America.'' Swire heads a group of British relatives of disaster victims called U.K. Families _ Flight 103. Transport Secretary Cecil Parkinson said he would call for a full investigation, and Swire would be invited to meet with department officials Monday to give details. ``We are already conducting a series of regular tests at airports all over the country,'' Parkinson said. A spokesman for Heathrow airport said airport officials are responsible for screening passengers and carry-on luggage, but individual airlines are responsible for screening checked baggage.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rains Leave Hundreds of Thousands Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains lashed southern Bangladesh Sunday, after a week of flooding that has left hundreds of thousands of people homeless and miles of crops destroyed. In the northern Sirajganj and Bogra districts, about 600,000 people were stranded and thousands of acres of crop destroyed when rivers overflowed. In the southern resort town of Cox Bazar, most streets were under almost three feet of water until late Saturday, said the official. A district official in Sirajganj, 60 miles northwest of the capital of Dhaka, said three children drowned Saturday, raising this year's monsoon death toll to five. Displaced villagers have sought shelter on patches of raised ground and many were living on roofs of concrete houses after their mud-and-straw huts were swept away, the Bengali-language newspaper, Ittefaq, said. Flooding is an annual problem in Bangladesh, where most land is only a few yards above sea level. In 1988, at least 1,400 people were killed in massive flooding. Bangladesh, with a population of 110 million, is one of the poorest nations in the world. Its annual per capita income is $160.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Workers Shut Down Oil Fields
DOC.TEXT: Striking workers began shutting down oil fields Sunday after last minute talks failed to settle a labor dispute, the union said. The Norwegian Federation of Oil Workers said in a statement it saw no end in sight to the strike, which began midnight Saturday. Norway's North Sea fields produced 1.63 million barrels a day of oil and 1.8 billion cubic meters of natural gas a month in April. Norway and Great Britain are Europe's largest petroleum producers. Municipalities Minister Johan J. Jakobsen, acting head of government while Prime Minister Jan P. Syse is abroad, summoned union leaders and business representatives large Saturday to urge continued negotiations. ``He asked them to keep talking because roughly 25 percent of Norway's national income comes from petroleum, and a strike could be grave for our economy,'' said Kjell Finnerud, a spokesman for the ministry. News reports estimated up to $31 million a day in lost income. Negotiations resumed, but quickly deadlocked ``because the Norwegian Confederation of Business and Industry had nothing to offer anyway,'' the 6,000 member union said in its release. The union said the 2.5 percent pay raise offered by the business confederation was less than half of its demand. The confederation said the union's members average annual wage of $49,000 is already 85 percent higher than the average wage in mainland industry.

DOC.HEAD: Elections Polarize, Rather Than Unite, Bulgaria
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with student rally, other developments; ADDS strikers demanding disclosure of election irregularities; EDITS to trim; No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The victory of former Communists in Bulgaria's first free elections has polarized this Balkan country rather than uniting it. Students have begun a nationwide protest that may swell into a major movement. The students first occupied Sofia university June 11, a day after a first round of elections indicated the Socialist Party _ formerly the Communists _ would triumph over the Union of Democratic Forces opposition coalition. Over the next few days, students at major universities in Sofia and several other cities joined the sit-in strike. On Sunday, about 15,000 students and supporters attended a downtown rally in Sofia organized by a national strike committee to back the protesters' demands. At first the media, the Socialists and even the Democratic Forces ignored the students. But now they and their supporters are taken increasingly seriously as a potential grass-roots revolt in Bulgaria. Striking students claim they have collected 130,000 signatures on petitions in their support, while a rival Movement of Students for Democracy says it has gathered 50,000 signatures from strike opponents. The Union of Cooperative Farms, an association of agricultural cooperatives, has threatened to block the main roads to Sofia with tractors and other vehicles unless the students end their strike by July 11. Even the protesters agree that change won't come swiftly. The lackadaisical air that accompanies much Bulgarian activity prevails at the university. A few hundred of the 12,000 students are actually taking part in a sit-in, most lolling on scorched lawns in the Balkan summer heat. The students began their strike to force disclosures of what they claim were irregularities in last month's elections _ the country's first multiparty balloting in 58 years. Their goals have since expanded to get the state TV director to resign for alleged bias in reporting and to investigate President Petar Mladenov's alleged consideration of using tanks against anti-government protests last winter. Behind these aims, however, is a larger goal of creating a changed society. ``The strike has shown the Bulgarian population that some people can think differently and that it is their right to demand things,'' said Nevyana Nikolova, an assistant English professor on strike at Sofia university. ``It forces people to take sides, something the Bulgarian has lacked over the years,'' said her colleague, Julia Stefanova. ``We don't want a new government, we want a new system.'' The end of hard-line Communist rule in Bulgaria came not, as in Romania, Czechoslovakia and East Germany, through street protest, but in a Communist Party coup in which some comrades ousted party chief Todor Zhivkov. The Communists reorganized as Socialists. After peaceful demonstrations by the fragmented but quickly growing opposition, the Socialists initiated negotiations that led to the June elections. In Sofia _ a Democratic Forces stronghold _ nearly everybody, including most Western diplomats, was shocked by the Socialists' 211-seat victory in the parliamentary elections. The Democratic Forces won 144 seats. Most people in Sofia have a tale to tell about what they call ``manipulations'' by the Socialists to secure votes in the villages. There are allegations the peasants were warned they'd lose their pensions, agricultural supplies or other benefits if they voted for the Democratic Forces. Cooler heads recognize the Democratic Forces concentrated too much on urban areas that the party probably would have carried anyway. Whatever the reason for the loss, it has pitted rural areas against towns, old against young, worker against intellectual. ``Fear of the known and fear of the unknown'' prevailed, said Stefanova, referring to the opposition's fear of the Socialists' past and the voters' fear of changes to come. Ironically, the outcome also complicated life for the victors. Socialist Premier Andrei Lukanov has indicated his reluctance to head a one-party government, preferring a coalition that might have more chance of attracting sorely needed foreign investment. But the opposition is currently adamant it won't help the Socialists solve the growing economic crisis created by their mismanagement. The new parliament will serve a two-year term and write a new constitution. Amid the anxieties, political intrigue and consumer shortages, the shadow of Romania's street violence looms large. Sofia residents look with apprehension at pictures of the miners that terrorized students and other government opponents in Bucharest and hope the violence will not travel south. ``Sofia is not yet Bucharest,'' reads the caption on a front-page picture in the weekly Sofia News. Inside the paper, journalist Krassimira Ikonomova voices a more widespread sentiment. ``We are afraid,'' she writes, ``because we are not yet free people. We are afraid that the first shy steps toward democracy could fail, as happened in Romania.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Official Says Reason for Optimism on Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 9th pvs, `Mosavian was...' to UPDATE with Iranian Interior Minister saying earthquake aid will not lead to improvement in diplomatic relations. Pickup 10th pvs, `Two American...'
DOC.TEXT: A London newspaper on Sunday quoted an Iranian Foreign Ministry official as saying one of the 15 Western hostages held in Lebanon could soon be freed. The Sunday Correspondent said in a report from Tehran that the Iranian official, Sayed Hossein Mosavian, refused in an interview to be more specific or to identify the hostage. But it quoted him as sayng, ``It is very optimistic news for you.'' The hostages _ six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss and one Italian _ are believed held by pro-Iranian extremists. Mosavian heads the West European bureau of Iran's Foreign Ministry, the newspaper said. It quoted him as saying the United States and other Western powers should exert influence on Israel to release Lebanese Shiite prisoners. Israel on Sunday freed 416 Palestinian prisoners from detention centers in what it called a gesture to mark the upcoming Moslem holiday of Eid al-Adha, the Israeli army said. It was not known whether there was any connection between the release and the Iranian official's remarks. The release of Palestinian and Shiite prisoners has been a longstanding demand of the hostage-takers. Mosavian was quoted as saying that Iran's influence in Lebanon was limited, but that the United States and Britain had ``unlimited'' influence over Israel and its Phalangist allies in Lebanon. In Iran, Interior Minister Abdollah Nouri said Sunday that despite generous foreign aid for victims of the June 21 earthquake that left 40,000 dead, Western nations will be disappointed if they seek political objectives with donations. ``Bilateral issues between nations and governments, whether general or fundamental, are not settled with such things,'' he said. Asked whether Iran wanted better relations with the United States, one of the countries to send aid, Nouri said, ``No.'' Two American hostages _ Frank Reed and Robert Polhill _ were freed in April. Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held hostage. He was abducted March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Second Plane Leaves State With Aid for Iran
DOC.TEXT: A relief agency distributed 40 tons of supplies to earthquake survivors in Iran on Sunday, but the official in charge of the shipment said it was ``embarrassing'' how little U.S. aid had gone to Iran. A cargo plane with the supplies arrived in Tehran Sunday morning and relief workers spent about six hours unloading it, said Stephen Norman, vice president of AmeriCares, a New Canaan-based relief organization. The plane, the second loaded by AmeriCares, left Bradley International Airport on Saturday. Tacked to the supplies were small signs reading ``Humanity is one body'' in English and Persian. An AmeriCares flight last weekend was the first U.S. relief effort to reach Iran in 11 years. U.S. government relief supplies were sent a day later. Doyt Conn, AmeriCares project director, said it was ``embarrassing'' that more U.S. supplies were not going to Iran. ``It's saddening. It's a shame,'' Conn said. AmeriCares has an abundance of supplies to send _ some were left behind on Saturday's flight _ but needs nearly $250,000 to charter the cargo planes for each trip, Conn said. ``If we can continue to raise the money to send these planes, we will continue to do this,'' he said. Susan Myrick, the mayor of Charlotte, N.C., and Charleston, S.C., Mayor Joseph Riley, have appealed to the nation's mayors to raise money for survivors of the quake that killed at least 40,000 people in Iran two weeks ago. ``The concern I have is that people are not really willing to reach out to the people of Iran'' because of longstanding tensions with the United States, said Myrick, who was present Saturday for the departure of the shipment. ``These people are just like us. They can't control what their government does,'' Myrick said. Her city has raised about $1,500 in donations, an amount she says is not nearly enough. When the first shipment arrived and the American gesture of kindness was revealed, the Iranians ``were stunned. Then they said, `You are welcome,''' said Katherine O'Sullivan, an AmeriCares volunteer who speaks Persian.
Contributions can be sent to AmeriCares at 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, Conn. 06840.

DOC.HEAD: Tall People Hold Heads High In Moonrakers Club
DOC.TEXT: Members of the New Jersey Moonrakers Club hold their heads high when they get together. They never meet in a place where they could bang heads on doorsills, and they don't have to endure corny comments about ``How's the weather up there?'' The Moonrakers Club is for tall people who prefer not to raise the roof. To belong, women must be at least 5-foot-10, and men, 6-foot-2. ``It's a chance to walk into a room and stand up straight,'' said Lin Damon, club president, 5-foot-11{. ``I always slouched. It helped me gain new confidence. Tall people become insecure at a young age,'' she said. Club rules are strict. If people don't measure up, they don't get in. Applicants are checked in their stocking feet. No 5-foot-7 women with three-inch spikes need apply, she said. Once in, though, allowances are made. ``We've had people shrink over the years, and they've maintained their membership,'' Ms. Damon said. ``But you can't claim you shrank before you applied.'' Members share their large-size problems, such as houses with low ceilings, uncomfortable airline seats and difficulty finding clothes that fit. ``Why do stores think tall people only want to wear polyester? We will spend money on clothes too,'' Damon said. The 100-member Moonrakers Club is part of Tall Clubs International, a 50-year-old organization that ranks development of the king-size bed among its biggest achievements. The Moonrakers' two tallest women are Maureen Ahlers of Hackensack and Ann Riesenman of Butler, both 6-foot-3, she said. Bob Burke of Woodridge leads the men at 6-foot-9. About the only thing members of the Moonrakers have in common is height. ``We have different occupations, different levels of schooling and a lot of different interests,'' said Damon, a purchasing agent for Williams and Watts, a military procurement and materials firm. There's another plus. ``You can start up a conversation at a bar with another tall person _ `You're tall, you might be interested in this.'''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Releases Prisoners on Eve of Moslem Holiday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Iranian Interior Minister saying West should not expect political benefits from earthquake aid; Edits to Trim; Pickup 7th pvs, `It was...'
DOC.TEXT: Israel freed more than 400 Palestinian prisoners from detention centers Sunday to mark the upcoming Moslem holiday of Eid al-Adha. Freeing Arab prisoners is traditional on religious holidays. But the timing of the release raised speculation it may be related to a report that a Western hostage may be freed in Lebanon or to Israel's efforts to make peace with Palestinians. At Megiddo prison in northern Israel _ site of the biblical Armageddon _ the first dozen of so Arabs were released in the early afternoon. Many flashed ``V for victory'' signs from the bus windows. By Sunday night, the army said 416 Palestinian inmates had been freed from facilities in the Gaza Strip, the Ketziot detention camp and Megiddo. In the hostage report from Tehran, The Sunday Correspondent of London quoted Sayed Hossein Mosavian, an Iranian Foreign Ministry official, as saying a Western hostage could be freed soon without any concession by the West. However, Mosavian also told the newspaper that the United States and other Western nations should exert influence on Israel to free its many Lebanese Shiite captives. In Iran, Interior Minister Abdollah Nouri said Sunday Western nations sending aid for victims of the June 21 earthquake that left 40,000 dead should not expect political benefits. Asked whether Iran wanted better relations with the United States, one of the countries to send aid, Nouri said, ``No.'' It was not clear if Israel's Lebanese Christian militia allies in Lebanon also intended to free prisoners for the Moslem holiday, which starts Monday. The Israeli-financed South Lebanon Army militia holds hundreds of Shiite prisoners at the El-Khiam detention camp in southern Lebanon. While Israel also holds Lebanese Shiites within its own territory, it appeared most of those being released Sunday were Palestinians arrested in the 30-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip.
