The Eid Al-Adha holidary, or feast of sacrifice, commemorates Abraham's offer to sacrifice his son for God. In Moslem belief the son is Ishmael. In Jewish tradition, Isaac was the son offered by Abraham. Dozens of Arab families from the occupied West Bank waited outside Megiddo prison for husbands, sons and brothers to be released. But many complained those being freed were almost at the end of their sentences. Subhi Abu Schedem, 18, from Hebron waited outside the prison for his brother Nader, 16. He said Nader had nine days left of a six-month sentence for stone-throwing and added: ``They only release prisoners who have two or three days left and not those that have 10 months or more. This is obvious propaganda.'' Dan Naveh, a chief aide to Defense Minister Moshe Arens, said the release of Arab prisoners is part of Arens' plan to coax Palestinians into peace talks by easing daily hardships. Naveh said Friday that prisoners being freed will have served the majority of a first sentence for participating in riots and would include juveniles under the age of 14. According to army statistics, Israel held 10,430 Arab security prisoners as of Friday. Of these, 4,341 have been convicted and 1,038 are being held under emergency regulations allowing suspects to be detained up to a year without charge or trial. The others are awaiting charges or trial. Also Sunday, a new leaflet by the pro-PLO leaders of the uprising called for Palestinians and Arab countries to boycott U.S.-made goods to protest American policies in the Middle East. In the Gaza Strip town of Rafah, masked Palestinians fatally stabbed an Arab suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities. The victim was identified as Zaher el-Houl, 30. The army confirmed the death and said police were investigating. El-Houl's death raised to 229 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs since the uprising began in December 1987. Most were suspected of collaboration or of dealing in drugs or prostitution. A total of 721 Palestinians have been killed by Israelis since the revolt began, and 45 Israelis have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Parents Can Now Disinherit Children
DOC.TEXT: A 165-year-old state law requiring that children get a minimum share of their parents' estate, the only law of its kind in the nation, was officially repealed Sunday. A parent can now disinherit a child for any reason _ or none _ as long as the child is over 23 and physically and mentally able to handle his affairs. Proponents say it was about time Louisiana residents enjoy the right to dispose of their property as they see fit. But critics claim that in an era of divorce and remarriage the new doctrine will remove an ancient protection for neglected children. Moreover, they say, the change will provoke intra-family warfare and stir up years of litigation in the courts. ``This looks like a lawyer's dream and a courtroom's nightmare,'' said attorney Catherine Soutullo. For 165 years, Louisiana has carried forward the philosophy of France's Napoleonic Code, demanding that children get some portion of their parents' estate. One child was guaranteed at least a fourth; two or more shared at least half. Parents could cut their children off for only 12 reasons, ranging from failing to ransom parents from captivity to failing to communicate with a parent for two years. Tulane Law School professor Cynthia Samuel said the new law will expose state courts to ugly lawsuits by children trying to invalidate a will on grounds that a beneficiary unduly influenced the parent. She also predicted more people would make wills, which they must do to take advantage of their new power to disinherit. ``You'd be amazed how much interest there is out there among some people who've followed this very closely, and who've been waiting to do this,'' Samuel said. Although Samuel acknowledged the old law sometimes forced parents to bequeath wealth to adult children who did not need it, she is more concerned about the loss of protection for children who did need it. The Legislature changed the forced heirship law last year, primarily at the urging of Chalin Perez, the former Plaquemines Parish president who has been feuding with the children from his first marriage for a decade.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Show Up At Statehouse To Vent Anger Against Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of residents gathered at the Statehouse on Sunday to protest a new package of higher taxes, taunting Gov. Jim Florio and President Bush with chants of ``Florio, Bush read our lips: No new taxes!'' The villain for most of the estimated 4,500 protesters was Florio, the Democratic governor who proposed a higher and expanded sales tax, a higher income tax, and increased taxes on items such as cigarettes and liquor. The $2.8 billion tax package will be used to close a budget gap of more than $1 billion, provide $1.1 billion in added state aid to public schools and ease some property taxes. All but the income tax took effect Sunday. The state sales tax, which increased from 6 percent to 7 percent, is the second highest in the country behind Connecticut's, which is 8 percent. The increased tax also was expanded to include some previously exempt items such as alcohol, cigarettes, telephone bills, soap and disposable paper goods. Many in the crowd, chanting ``Recall, Recall!'' and ``Florio Must Go!,'' held up rolls of toilet paper, one of several items to be taxed for the first time. But the rally organizers stressed their anger toward a Democratic governor did not mean they supported Republicans, who this week attempted to make political hay out of the rally as a prelude to next year's legislative elections. ``They make promises and they don't keep them,'' said John Budzash, 39, a postal worker from Howell who helped organize the rally. ``We can't take these tax increases. But the Republicans are as much to blame as the Democrats.'' Budzash said the organizers, calling themselves ``Hands Across New Jersey,'' want the tax hikes repealed and a ``complete audit of state government to see where our money goes.'' He said by August the group wanted to give Florio a petition with the names of one million people against taxes. The protest began when Budzash made a telephone call to radio station WKXW and called for a Statehouse rally. Other listeners responded and the station, which serves most of the state, repeatedly plugged the rally.

DOC.HEAD: Pitcher Tosses Another No-Hitter _ And Losses, 4-0
DOC.TEXT: Andy Hawkins of the New York Yankees pitched the sixth no-hitter in major league baseball this season and the third in less than 48 hours on Sunday, but lost 4-0 to the Chicago White Sox because of errors. The only other pitcher to lose a complete-game, no-hitter was Houston's Ken Johnson against Cincinnati in 1964. The Reds won that game 1-0. With the bases loaded and two outs in the eighth inning, Chicago's Robin Ventura hit a deep fly to left fielder Jim Leyritz, normally a third baseman. Leyritz appeared in position to make the catch, but the ball glanced off his glove for a two-base error, allowing three runs to score. The next batter, Ivan Calderon, hit a fly to right that Jesse Barfield lost in the sun. The ball bounced off his glove and Ventura scored to give the White Sox a 4-0 lead. On Friday night, Dave Stewart of the Oakland Athletics and Fernando Valenzuela of the Los Angeles Dodgers pitched no-hitters in separate games. It was the first time in major league history that no-hitters were pitched in each league on the same day.

DOC.HEAD: Government Looks For New Ways To Slow Highway Speeders
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS first three grafs to CORRECT that government, not insurance group, is looking into proliferation of radar detectors; SUBS 14th graf, `It unleashes,' to conform as second reference to Miller
DOC.TEXT: Government traffic safety experts, in their never-ending effort to curb highway speeding, hope to use an old weapon in a new way they believe will convince some heavy-footed drivers to ease up on their accelerators. Federal officials are looking for ways to get stationary radar units at highway construction sites, dangerous curves and other areas. The idea is that speeding drivers who use radar detectors will slow down, not realizing that the nearest trooper might be miles away. Jeffrey Miller, deputy director of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said the plan would require Federal Communications Commission cooperation. He said it could turn radar detectors into safety tools. But advocates for radar detectors, which are owned by between 12 million and 15 million drivers, say the gadgets are the best defense motorists have against radar errors and unwarranted tickets. Radar detector opponents, including the government and insurance companies, categorize the devices with burglary tools. Both, they say, are used by lawbreakers. Brian O'Neill, head of the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, said a study conducted in Maryland and Virginia showed that one out of every eight cars has a radar detector, while nearly a third of big trucks have them. The study showed that 22 percent of cars without the units exceeded the speed limit, while more than 40 percent of those with detectors drove faster than the posted limits. The study revealed as many vehicles with radar detectors in Virginia, where they are illegal, as in neighboring Maryland, where they are allowed. Laws banning radar detectors in Virginia, Connecticut, and Washington, D.C., date back to the 1960s. The only recent statute is a scheduled New York ban of the units in commercial vehicles. In California, state police must pace speeders the old fashioned way because that state's legislature refuses to allow them to use radar. However, some local police use it. Some insurance companies have tried to avoid accepting customers with radar detectors. But the Government Employees Insurance Co. (GEICO) has found it tough to defend its refusal of insurance to radar detector users. In March, a Maryland court ruled against the practice, and surcharges for detector users have been struck down by insurance company regulators in several other states. ``We're not interested in people who tell us up front they're planning to speed. We're not interested in lawbreakers,'' GEICO spokesman August Alegi said. In 1986, Congress rejected a move to force states that raise speed limits from 55 mph to 65 mph to outlaw radar detectors. ``It unleashed such a torrent of irate letters and telegrams that, so far as I know, nobody in Congress has mentioned the subject since,'' said the NHTSA's Miller. ``When something is that widespread and popular, it's difficult to attack it successfully,'' he said. Miller said speed has been underestimated as a major national safety problem with the focus on seat belts and anti-drunken driving efforts. The NHTSA is backing an experiment on the Capital Beltway, the busy freeway that circles Washington, D.C., in which a photograph is taken of a speeding vehicle and a ticket mailed to the owner. The system, in which no tickets will initially be issued, has raised the concern of the American Civil Liberties Union, the American Automobile Association and other groups. ``There goes due process out the window,'' said Chuck Terlizzi, Maryland coordinator for the National Motorists Association. Government and private safety advocates also are using or considering other ways of catching speeders, including devices that employ laser beams or measure speed without emitting a radar beam.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Denies Involvement in Amsterdam Bombing
DOC.TEXT: The Irish Republican Army denied responsibility for the bombing of the British tourism office in Amsterdam, the British news agency Press Association reported Sunday. The news agency said it was notified ``through the usual channels'' that the IRA disclaimed responsibility for the attack, which damaged windows at the office in the Dutch capital Saturday. The building also houses the South African national tourist office and an office for Spain's Iberia Airlines. Dublin's Downtown Radio said it had also received word that ``the IRA categorically denies any involvement'' in the Amsterdam attack. The IRA has attacked British targets in continental Europe as part of its campaign to drive the British out of Northern Ireland and unite the Protestant-dominated province with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: American Peace Corps Worker Held by Rebels in Philippines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 6th pvs, `Embassy spokesman ...,' to ADD remarks by Scowcroft that U.S. officials heard of disappearance last week; Pickup 7th graf pvs: Last week ...
DOC.TEXT: Communist rebels have kidnapped an American Peace Corps member, but U.S. authorities said Sunday they learned of the abduction only after other volunteers were ordered to leave last week. Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was taken by gunmen June 13 from his home in Patag, a remote village in the mountains of Negros Island, Philippine and U.S. sources said. Swanson was believed the first Peace Corps volunteer kidnapped by the rebels and the first American held by the New People's Army since nine airmen were detained briefly in 1986. In Kennebunkport, Maine where he was vacationing, President Bush called the kidnapping a sign of ``the age of the terrorist.'' ``We've been very much worried about this,'' he said. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said American officials learned of Swanson's disappearance Saturday after trying to contact him as part of the evacuation of Peace Corps volunteers from the Philippines. But Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, told reporters, ``We first heard about it maybe a week ago, close to a week ago.'' Last week, the United States recalled the 261 Peace Corps volunteers in the country after intelligence reports indicated that Communist rebels might try to kill or kidnap them. American authorities had said previously that all the volunteers were accounted for. The volunteers began leaving the Philippines on Friday. Schrager said American officials rushed to Negros to discuss ways to win Swanson's release, but said the United States would not pay ransom for the Peace Corps worker's freedom. On Sunday, the retired Roman Catholic bishop of Negros, the Rev. Antonio Fortich, said Swanson had been friendly with New People's Army guerrillas. Swanson's father, Leonard, said in an interview in Cheyenne on Sunday that his son knew rebels in the area where he worked on a reforestation project but that he never considered them a threat. ``He tried to be friendly with all the folks in the village and all who he encountered,'' Swanson's father said. ``I was dismayed, of course,'' to learn of the kidnapping, he said. ``I guess here in Cheyenne we would ask for people's prayers.'' According to Fortich, four to eight armed rebels came to Swanson's home in the Negros mountains last month and told his Filipino wife, Merly, they were ``borrowing'' her husband. The couple were married May 29 in a ceremony attended by Swanson's parents, Leonard Swanson said. Fortich said the wife received a note from her husband last week saying he was well but asking for his glasses, reading materials and clothes. She left the items in a bag outside their home and a rebel courier retrieved it at night, Fortich said. Swanson asked his wife not to notify authorities and she did so only after hearing of the order to evacuate Peace Corps members. President Corazon Aquino's press secretary, Tomas Gomez, said the embassy notified Philippine officials of the disappearance Saturday. Gomez said the kidnapping might have been avoided if the United States had consulted Philippine authorities on security. ``They refused to listen to a security briefing,'' Gomez said. ``Maybe if they did that, we could have prevented it.'' Schrager said the embassy had dispatched diplomats to the Negros city of Bacolod. Negros, 300 miles southeast of Manila, is a stronghold of the rebel New Peoples Army, which has waged a 21-year-old insurgency and seeks to establish a Marxist state in the Philippines. On May 29, rebels on Negros kidnapped a Japanese aid worker, Fumio Mizuno, and are believed holding him in mountains near Bacolod. Fortich has been trying to negotiate Mizuno's release. The U.S. decision to withdraw the Peace Corps volunteers drew criticism from Philippines officials, who said the United States was overreacting to the alleged threats. Although the move was expected to have little impact on international aid programs, the withdrawal was embarassing to the Aquino government, which is increasingly sensitive to its international image. Communist rebels are believed to have killed eight Americans since April 1989 but they had made no public threat against the Peace Corps. U.S. officials also said the Peace Corps office in Manila would remain open as a sign that the withdrawal was temporary.

DOC.HEAD: Traditionalists Use Force in Effort to Take Over Cathedral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING TO MAKE 2ND LD-WRITETHRU
DOC.TEXT: A fight erupted after Mass at the local cathedral Sunday when traditionalist Roman Catholics, shoving the vicar aside, tried to move in to celebrate their own service in Latin. Punches were thrown, the organ sounded and candles went flying down an aisle as the estimated 60 traditionalists tried to take over the main altar at the St. Maclou Cathedral following regular Sunday Mass. A policeman tried to mediate the brawl, which continued for more than an hour, ending when The Rev. Andre Berrere agreed to say his Latin Mass in a side chapel. The incident began about 11:30 a.m. when the group of traditionalists, organized by the militant Committee Saint Genevieve of Argenteuil, marched to the main altar of the cathedral in this northern suburb of Paris. The cathedral vicar, the Rev. Jean-Marie Human, surrounded by altar boys and other faithful, blocked the way to the main altar, considered by church law the symbol of ecclesiastical authority in the diocese. Several times, the traditionalists tried to shove aside the vicar, according to witness accounts. At one point, Human sounded the organs in protest as defenders moved into the choir area, witnesses said. By 1 p.m., the traditionalists gave up the idea of using the main altar for their Mass. They left after celebrating a Latin Mass in a side chapel. No one was seriously injured in the melee. The attempted takeover of the cathedral was the fourth such effort since the start of the year by the committee, which is pressing the Pontoise diocese to put an unused chapel at their disposal for Latin Masses. The Second Vatican Council (1962-65) suppressed the use of the 16th-century version of the Latin Mass and established the use of the local language. The reform was intended to make the ceremony more accessible to the faithful. Some Catholics dislike the new Mass, and have joined the traditionalist movement of French Archbishop Marcel Lefebvre. He was excommunicated two years ago for consecrating four bishops in defiance of papal orders. Two years ago, Pope John Paul II urged bishops to provide a ``full and generous'' use of a 1984 decree allowing use of the Tridentine Mass under special circumstances. His order was an attempt to reach out to people uncomfortable with the new Mass.

DOC.HEAD: 24 Injured When Lightning Hits Pavilion
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES throughout with details on scene, names of injured children, comments; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Lightning struck a pavilion where members of a hunting club huddled for shelter during a Sunday thunderstorm, and 24 people were injured, at least four critically, officials said. The 25 members of the Kingwood Pike Coon Hunters Club had been holding bow and arrow target practice and sought refuge from torrential rains that swept the area about 80 miles south of Pittsburgh, said Ed Turnley, a Reedsville Volunteer Fire Department member. A bolt of lightning struck a wooden support post on the tin-roofed pavilion, and it burst into splinters, he said. ``It was kind of a state of confusion. People were scattered everywhere,'' Turnley said. All but one of the injured were conscious when rescue workers arrived, he said. The injured were taken to two hospitals in nearby Morgantown, Turnley said. The four in critical condition included 13-year-old David McDonald and 12-year-old Ronald Robinson Jr. Both boys were from Morgantown. Two others, including 8-year-old Brian Plum of Dellslow, were in good condition, while four others were in fair condition and four in stable condition. Eight others were treated and released and no status report was available for the two others. The victims complained of chest pains, burns and other ailments associated with electrical shock, said nursing supervisor Tammy Henderson at Monongalia General Hospital. Thunderstorms, hail and heavy winds raked portions of northern and eastern West Virginia, knocking out power to 1,000 homes and business, officials said. ``There were trees and power lines down all over the place,'' said Gary Shaver, a dispatcher for the Preston County Sheriff's Department. ``A tree fell on a trailer and several trees fell onto roads.'' ``It's been really bad up here. We've had trees falling through lines, trees uprooted, lightning. We have some very tired linemen,'' she said. Barbour County, south of Kingwood, got an inch of rain in a 15-minute downpour, said Barbour County Sheriff's Department dispatcher J.R. Carman.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Denounces Kidnapping of Peace Corps Volunteer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf pvs, Bush hoped, with one graf to show golf ended upbeat; picks up 11th graf pvs, Earlier Sunday
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Sunday decried the kidnapping of a Peace Corps volunteer by communist rebels in the Philippines. The president, in a brief exchange with reporters after he teed off on a round of golf, said, ``We've been very much worried about this.'' U.S. sources said Timothy Swanson, 26, of Cheyenne, Wyo., was taken at gunpoint June 13 from his home in Patag, a remote village in the mountains of Negros Island, Philippine. However, officials said they only learned of the abduction on Saturday. The United States ordered its 261 Peace Corps volunteers home from the Philippines last week because of terrorist threats. ``We pulled them out of there, they're coming out anyway,'' said the president, who called the kidnapping a sign of ``the age of the terrorist. It's not good.'' A U.S. Embassy spokesman in Manila said U.S. officials did not learn of Swanson's disappearance until Saturday when officials tried to inform him of the evacuation. But Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, told reporters, ``We first heard about it maybe a week ago, close to a week ago.'' Bush, midway through an extended Fourth of July holiday weekend at his Oceanfront home here, confessed to being in a foul mood on the day his mother, Dorothy Walker Bush, was celebrating her 89th birthday. ``It's just not one of the big bonanza days,'' Bush said. ``It's been that kind of a day. Lost in tennis, no fish, no particularly good news from around the world. And, you know, just one of those days.'' Bush later changed his assessment when he made a birdie on the 13th hole of a local golf course. ``It's the second happiest day of my life, from a bad day starting off,'' he told reporters who pressed him on what the happiest day was. He thrust his right thumb upward and said, ``Barbara.'' Earlier Sunday, tourists sang ``Happy Birthday'' to Bush's mother as she emerged from St. Ann's by the Sea Episcopal Church on the arm of her son. ``Thanks for the greeting for my mom,'' said the vacationing president, clad in a kelly green blazer, dark slacks and white shoes. Mrs. Bush, whose father purchased the property at Walker's Point that became the family's summer homestead early in this century, appeared to relish the attention. Her birthday also was noted from the altar during the service by both the rector, the Rev. Laman H. Bruner Jr., and Episcopal Bishop Edward Chalfant, who delivered the sermon. The bishop praised Bush, who is here preparing for a NATO summit in London this week, for ``your courageous witness'' for world peace. He said the president over the past year has been ``an instrument of God for the possibility of world peace and an unimaginable global harmony.'' Four generations of Bushes attended the service, including the president's daughter, Dorothy LeBlond, and her two children, Sam and Ellie, who helped pass the collection plates. The president is a vestryman of the 102-year-old stone church, which is only open from the last Sunday in June until the day before Labor Day. Bush later played tennis and golf on this third-day of an extended weekend. On Saturday night, Bush received a call from Nelson Mandela, who ``thanked the president for his support for the struggle to end apartheid'' and for the reception Mandela recived on his American tour, said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The deputy president of the African National Congress visited the White House last week during his eight-day tour of the United States. Bush planned to grapple with issues affecting world peace Monday. Vice President Dan Quayle, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will join Bush and Scowcroft at Walker's Point for a final strategy session before the NATO summit Thursday and Friday. U.S. officials confirmed a report in Sunday editions of The Washington Post that the United States at the London summit would propose to eventually remove all 1,400 nuclear-tipped artillery shells now deployed in West Germany and elsewhere in Europe. Bush also will huddle Tuesday with Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady and other officials to go over last-minute planning for the July 9-11 economic summit in Houston with the major industrialized nations. He will depart Kennebunkport for London on Wednesday evening after a five-day stay in this seaside resort where he has come every summer of his life except 1944 when he was flying bomber missions in the Pacific during World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Swanson's Father Says Son Knew Members Of New Peoples' Army
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Philippines in 6th and final grafs
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Philippines-US
DOC.TEXT: A Peace Corps volunteer kidnapped by the New People's Army in the Philippines knew several members of the Communist group but never believed he would be targeted by the insurgents, his father said Sunday. The U.S. Embassy in Manila said Sunday that Timothy Swanson, 26, appeared to have been abducted June 13 by members of the rebel group that has been waged a 21-year insurgency and seeks to establish a Marxist state. Officials said Timothy Swanson's wife received a letter from him last week saying he was all right and asking her to send some items. Leonard Swanson said his son had been stationed on the central island of Negros since February 1988 and was working in a reforestation project. ``He knew who some of the (New People's Army) people were and because of the remote location he was assigned to, he tried to get along with them,'' he said. ``He tried to be friendly with all the folks in the village and all who he encountered.'' Swanson and his wife, Lynne, visited the Philippines to attend their son's wedding on May 29. Peace Corps officials informed them Saturday that Timothy had been kidnapped. ``We were there about a month ago ... and he ackowledged that yes, the NPA is present and that ... the NPA seemed to be leaving the Peace Corps volunteers alone,'' he said. ``And, well, the tensions ... didn't seem to be that present on Negros.'' Timothy Swanson graduated from Cheyenne East High School in 1982 before attending the University of Chicago, where he studied geography, his father said. Last week, the U.S. government recalled the 261 Peace Corps volunteers in the Philippines after reports indicated that Communist rebels might try to kill or kidnap them. U.S. Embassy officials said they were unable to contact Swanson when the withdrawal was announced.

DOC.HEAD: Security Intensified After Government Renews Extraditions
DOC.TEXT: Security was intensified in the capital Sunday after the government extradited two suspected drug traffickers to the United States _ the first such extraditions in three months. Additional army checkpoints were set up in downtown Bogota and patrols were increased apparently out of fear that terrorists working for the traffickers might try to retaliate. The government had not extradited any drug traffickers to the United States for three months. Officials gave no explanation for resuming the extraditions. Two suspects, Rafael Juliao Fernandez, 44, and Luis Cabarcas, 60, were flown to the United States on a Drug Enforcement Administration plane early Sunday morning. They were turned over to U.S. authorities at the Bogota international airport late Saturday. U.S. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, in a statement released Sunday in Washington, said the extraditions demonstrate ``the continued determination of the Colombian government to battle the Colombian drug cartel'' and ``to bring these drug dealing suspects to justice.'' The U.S. Marshals Service said Juliao is being held for arraignment in New York City on charges of distributing and conspiracy to distribute cocaine. Cabarcas is charged with leading a drug trafficking ring in North Carolina, the U.S. marshals service said in Washington. He was among 39 people indicted in 1985 on charges that included conspiracy to possess and distribute 2 million methaqualone tablets and more than 1,000 pounds of marijuana. Both men were held for six months in a Colombian jail while they awaited the government's final decision on extradition. Authorities are currently holding 13 other Colombians wanted in the United States on drug charges. So far, 17 people have been extradited from Colombia to the United States since the government of President Virgilio Barco declared war on the drug cartels last August in retaliation for the assassination of a presidential candidate. The Medellin drug cartel responded by declaring a ``total war'' against the government. At least 288 Colombians have been killed in car bombings and other terrorist attacks since August. The most recent attacks have taken place in Medellin, Colombia's second city, where the world's largest cocaine cartel is based. Last Thursday a car bomb outside a Medellin police station killed 16 people and wounded 30 others. The drug lords have also hired gunmen to assassinate police officers in Medellin. Two policemen were shot and killed late Friday, bringing to 152 the number of police killed in the Medellin region since January. In another development, Bogota's El Espectador newspaper reported Sunday that the government had authorized military judges to tap the phone line of anyone suspected of having links to drug traffickers. The presidential decree authorizing the taps was one of several emergency measures adopted last week to fight drug terrorism, El Espectador reported. On Wednesday, the government decreed emergency measures, including one requiring all Colombian families to register with police. The Colombian press and many lawyers have criticized the registration measure, saying it violates Colombians' right to privacy.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Air Show Crash, 2nd Ld - Writethru, a0763,0379
DOC.HEAD: Sixth Stunt Show Pilot Killed in Two Months
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf, ```He came...' to CORRECT identification for source; SUBS 11th graf, `A June 17th...' to ADD location of crash
DOC.TEXT: A stunt pilot crashed a World War II-era plane into the Niagara River and died Sunday in the sixth fatal air show accident in the United States in five weeks. The body of the pilot, Giff Foley, 43, was found in the AT-6 plane under 18 feet of water near the river's entrance to Lake Erie, officials said. Foley lost control during a manuever before thousands of people attending a festival in Buffalo and across the river in Fort Erie, Ontario. ``He came by on his first pass and he went inverted,'' said Mason Dunn, a sound technician for the Coors Light Silver Bullet jet team. ``It looked like he was trying to go to the American side when it looked like he began losing altitude.'' Also Sunday, a stunt pilot flying a vintage World War II plane was killed in Ottawa, Ontario. Harry Tope, 47, of Mount Pleasant, Mich., was completing the bottom end of a loop when the engine of his Mustang P-51 sputtered and he crashed. A pilot crashed and died Saturday in Groton, Conn., while attempting a stunt takeoff of his 1942 Stearman biplane in an air show, state police said. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Robert Buckhorn said he did not have statistics on small plane accidents from last year and could not comment on whether there have been an unusually large number of fatal accidents. The other accidents, each claiming the life of the pilot, included: _ a June 23, crash of a P-51 Mustang plane during an air show in Abilene, Texas. _ a June 17 crash in Oklahoma City of a Soviet-made Sukhoi-26M, which failed to come out of an intentional stall during a show in front of about 75,000 people. _ a June 14 crash of a single-engine plane during practice for an air show in Zeeland, Mich. _ a May 26 crash of a jet in a maneuver during an air show in Tuskegee, Ala.

DOC.HEAD: Breakaway African-American Sings Support for Barry
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, under trial on drug and perjury charges, got a rousing ovation Sunday at the first anniversary service for Bishop George Augustus Stallings' breakaway Roman Catholic congregation. Stallings, who was barred last week from attending Barry's trial, praised the mayor in a rousing ceremony that included traditional African dress, song and dance. The congregation joined him in singing ``That's What Friend Are For'' to Barry and his wife, Effi. ``They figured that since Mayor Marion Barry couldn't get bought, he had to get caught,'' Stallings told his Imani Temple African-American Congregation. ``That's why Mayor Marion Barry is in trouble right now, he is too smart, too intelligent, too black.'' Stallings also praised Effi Barry for standing by the mayor while a parade of witnesses testifies about his alleged drug use and love affairs. ``When I get married I want to find me a woman just like Effi Barry,'' he said. Barry last week faced some of the toughest testimony yet at his trial and prosecutors released a videotape of the hotel room sting in which the mayor allegedly smoked crack cocaine. On Saturday, Barry was cheered at an anti-drug rally and told the crowd his legal situation is ``just a matter of good lawyers and good jurors.'' U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson last week said Stallings and Nation of Islam Minister Louis Farrakhan could not observe the trial as Barry's guests. Stallings, who was excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church earlier this year after forming his breakaway congregation for disenchanted black Catholics, said he plans to join an American Civil Liberties Union suit Monday with Farrakhan appealing Jackson's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Santa Barbara Residents Attend Services After Week of Havoc
With AM-Fires
DOC.TEXT: As firefighting helicopters thundered overhead, residents attended religious services Sunday to give thanks and seek solace after an unforgettable week. With the fire that ravaged their community finally circled, the congregation at Coast Community Church of the Nazarene stood and sang, ``This is the day the Lord has made.'' ``It's good to be here,'' said Jim Hopper, who helped his in-laws out of their hillside home, which escaped flames. ``In some ways it's an act of God we were spared.'' The widely scattered fires _ ranging from Santa Barbara 200 miles south to San Diego County, killed two people, destroyed or damaged 520 homes and burned 22,000 acres, officials said. The church, just a few blocks from a devastated Park Highlands neighborhood, is beyond a checkpoint where police threaten to fine fire-scene gawkers $500. The Rev. Ira True told the congregation he had to rely on faith just to get to his job. ``I told the highway patrolman, `I'm here to preach.' He said, `That sounds like a good idea to me,' and let me in,''' True said. True read to the congregation from Isaiah, Chapter 43: ``When you pass through the waters I will be with you.'' But he did not read the next verse, perhaps just too much for this Sunday: ``When you walk through the fire you will not be burned. The flames will not set you ablaze.'' The noise from a helicopter also punctuated services at Saint Raphael's Catholic Church, where many parishioners lost homes. Churchgoers there heard about the liturgy of rebirth through baptism. ``The liturgy for today is appropriate for what has happened in Santa Barbara,'' said Rev. Vincent McMurray. ``Let us remember that through death and death situations, we enter into new life.'' In the church hall, about 250 boxes of donated clothing awaited parishioners who needed items. Parishioner Rosemary Varesio said many congregation members had lost their homes, but none had yet come to collect the clothes. ``I guess they might not have any place to keep clothing,'' she said. At the Congregation B'Nai B'Rith, flames came within two feet of the building. Congregation members credit custodian Marian Grodel with saving both the synagogue and its torahs. As flames approached, Grodel turned on the sprinklers, loaded the temple van with the torahs and drove away. ``I had no time to talk,'' said Grodel, ``It was my duty.'' Temple spokeswoman Evely Shlensky said the regular Sabbath service on Friday ``was one of thanksgiving and commiseration'' because 18 families in the community lost their homes. ``When there is so much destruction you really realize the sense of community,'' Shlensky said. ``There is the devastation, but the families were taken care of.''

DOC.SECOND: AM-Body Parts Found, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0786,0269
DOC.HEAD: Environmentalist Slain, Mutilated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf to CORRECT spelling of name to Oliveira sted Oliveria
DOC.TEXT: Body parts found dumped in two yellow plastic trash bags along a roadway were identified Sunday as the remains of an environmental activist last seen canvassing door-to-door in a rural area. Sgt. William Vyvyan of the Racine County Sheriff's Department identified the victim as James Michael Madden, 24, of Whitefish Bay. Vyvyan said Madden had been soliciting donations for Citizens for a Better Environment when he disappeared last week. He was last seen Wednesday evening in an area of scattered homes and farms. The garbage bags were discovered by area residents Friday along a highway outside Racine about 2{ miles from where Madden was last seen, authorities said. ``We are just shocked and tremendously saddened. We are numb,'' said Rosemary Oliveira, the environmental group's state administrative director. Madden had worked for the group about two months and was ``extremely well-liked,'' she said. ``He was an avid environmentalist. He was very devoted to the cause.'' Asked about the circumstances of the death _ an environmentalist found in plastic trash bags _ she said authorities had told her the death is not believed to be related to the organization. ``My own feeling is this is some psychopath out there,'' she said. Madden's upper torso was found in one bag and his pelvis and legs in another, Vyvyan said. His head and arms have not been recovered, he said. Authorities have said there were several stab wounds on the body.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Search for Cause and Cure to `Sea Lice' Welts
DOC.TEXT: No one knows exactly what is attacking bathers along a 60-mile stretch of Florida's Atlantic Coast, but the so-called ``sea lice'' has left beachgoers with nasty red welts on their bodies. Despite the name, health officials aren't certain that insects are to blame. Jack Nolan, of the Palm Beach County Public Health Unit's epidemiology group, said all officials know is the rash occurs most often between April and July when the water temperature varies between 78 and 82 degrees. Each spring and summer for the past decade, unsuspecting swimmers from Deerfield Beach to Jensen Beach have returned home to have their bodies erupt in welts that look like insect bites and itch like poison ivy. ``It's itchy. It's uncomfortable, and my daughter ran a temperature with it,'' said Mary Morgan of Boca Raton. ``We do like the beach, and we'd like to go back. But we're a little leery until we know what this is.'' The county and several beach patrols have commissioned studies to find the culprit and the cure for the ailment, also known as sea bather's eruption and Gulf Coast itch. Pharmacists and beach patrols suggest remedies ranging from Calamine lotion to Benadryl to a bath in wet oatmeal.

DOC.HEAD: Charity Pop Concert Entertains 100,000
DOC.TEXT: More than 100,000 fans were wild delight as Paul McCartney launched into ``I Saw Her Standing There,'' and ``Back in the U.S.S.R.'' during an all-star charity concert. Pouring rain failed to dampen spirits at the charity concert at Knebworth Park, 20 miles north of London late Saturday. Most fans came prepared with umbrellas and plastic raincoats, but the sun eventually broke through. The lineup included Elton John, Status Quo, Cliff Richard, The Shadows, Phil Collins, Eric Clapton, Mark Knopfler, Robert Plant and Pink Floyd. All donated their time to help raise the equivalent of $10.5 million for handicapped children and young musicians. The money will be divided evenly between the Nordoff-Robbins music therapy project, which uses music to motivate children with mental, physical or emotional difficulties, and a new school for performing arts. Despite a heavy downpour as Tears for Fears kicked off the day-long extravaganza, fans from all over the country were quick to join in. Old favorites Status Quo got the crowd going with ``Rockin' All Over the World.'' And Cliff Richard accompanied by The Shadows received thunderous applause for ``Summer Holiday.'' One of the biggest cheers of the night was for former Beatle McCartney, who was introduced by James Bond star Timothy Dalton. The concert was televised around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Union Optimistic in Negotiations with Chiquita
DOC.TEXT: The leader of striking Chiquita employees said Sunday he was optimistic after officials from the U.S. fruit company joined talks on worker demands for their first pay increase in six years. ``The situation has improved _ mainly because Chiquita is now at the negotiating table with us,'' union president Rene Ayestas said. The union represents Chiquita's 10,000 workers in Honduras. Ayestas said there have been no results from the talks, which began Saturday, but added that ``anything could happen if there is flexibility on both parts.'' Company officials had no comment. Chiquita workers went on strike Thursday and company officials immediately branded the strike illegal and said they would not pay higher wages. Thousands of other workers _ including those at Honduras' only oil refinery _ struck in solidarity. The workers are still on strike and Honduras is likely to run out of fuel early this week if the labor dispute is not resolved. Business and political leaders have voiced fears the spreading strike could destablize Honduras, the poorest nation in the hemisphere after Haiti, and President Rafael Leonardo Callejas last week dispatched a mediating commission. The commission and union officials have been talking for a week but the company only joined the negotiations Saturday. The workers, who make an average of $15.32 a day, have asked for a 60 percent raise. Their last pay increase was in 1984. After a 10-day strike last October, the company agreed to review wages but has taken no action. ``There is a lot of distrust on both sides and they are asking for many guarantees to any accords,'' said Congressman Mariano Gonzalez, a member of the presidential mediating commission. ``But what is important is that they are negotiating directly.'' The Cincinnati-based Chiquita, formerly United Fruit, has been a major power in Honduras since the early part of the century. It now controls about 60 percent of the nation's banana exports. A subsidiary of New York-based Standard Fruit controls most of the remainder of the trade. Bananas are the leading export of this Tennessee-sized nation of 4.8 million. Honduras was the first Central American nation to be dubbed a ``banana republic'' after the immense power wielded by U.S. fruit companies.

DOC.HEAD: Trail of Art Treasures Reads Like Hollywood Script
DOC.TEXT: Lost treasure. International intrigue. A lone adventurer. The script for a Hollywood movie? Nope, this is a job for Willi A. Kotre, an investigator who followed a trail of musty documents, Cold War secrets and just plain luck to discover the lost treasure of the Quedlinburg Cathedral in East Germany. ``But please, don't call me Indiana Jones,'' the soft-spoken German said. The 36-year-old Kotre, a researcher for the Prussian Cultural Heritage Foundation in Berlin, in May pinpointed a local bank as the place where a dead former U.S. Army officer's heirs were keeping the missing gifts of Germany's earliest kings. Now, the art's original owner, the Lutheran Church of Quedlinburg, is suing the family of former Lt. Joe T. Meador for return of the treasures. Meador died in 1980, bequeathing the artwork to his brother, Jack Meador, and sister, Jane Cook. Lawyers for the church contend Meador stole the treasures in the final days of World War II, mailed them to the U.S. and kept them in his hometown of Whitewright, about 60 miles north of Dallas. German officials want to bring the artwork home as a symbol of German reunification. ``It is very difficult to take a historical account and successfully trace a missing item to an individual,'' Korte said. ``Usually, you need some kind of postwar event _ like someone trying to sell the art _ and then you have a case. ``That's what happened here.'' An East German who helped in the case, Gunter Wermusch, told The Dallas Morning News in a telephone interview from Berlin that Nazi officials hauled the cathedral's treasures into the cave as Allied troops approached in early 1945. Soon after Korte's search began, a London book dealer offered one of the missing treasures, a 9th-century illuminated manuscript, to the researcher's employer. Officials said the $9 million offer was rejected in late 1988 because of the price and potential problems from buying art taken from another country. But it provided a clue that the dealer apparently worked for a U.S. resident, they said. Korte said he began looking for detailed accounts of Army units near Quedlinburg in April 1945. Spending months in the National Archives records tracing U.S. operations, he then went to the National Personnel Records Center in St. Louis, the military's service records repository. More than 1,000 names of soldiers assigned to the area were found by Korte in over a week of research. He then turned to East Germans and medieval art experts for further clues. Bavarian manuscript dealer Heribert Tenschert in February was offered the illuminated manuscript, which had been in Europe without a buyer for two years, the newspaper said. Tenschert said he relayed the offer to the Foundation of the States, a private German cultural group. The foundation paid $3 million to Houston attorney John T. Torigian in April for the manuscript, said Aoachim Fischer, a foundation director. Torigian termed himself a proxy for an unnamed U.S. client, Fischer said. Dealers left out of the sale immediately began talking, said Korte. ``Eventually, I learned the name of the bank, and it was short work once I had that,'' he said. In May, Korte went to the First National Bank of Whitewright, which was holding the artwork for the Meador family. Bank president John Farley said he talked with Korte but gave him no information about the treasures. Checks of his lists and a call to a Grayson County veterans' group produced Joe Meador's name, said Korte. The Germans negotiated in successive weeks with the bank and Torigian, who represents the Meador family, the foundation said. But talks stalled on June 16, when word surfaced of a second manuscript in Switzerland that was offered for $500,000. A Dallas judge has barred movement of the artwork.

DOC.HEAD: Dole: Bush Won't Try To Boost Income Tax Rate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new grafs 8-11, ``On the CBS-TV ...,' to UPDATE with comments from Republican pollster appearing on `Face the Nation.' Pickup 8th graf pvs. Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Senate Republican leader Bob Dole said Sunday he does not expect President Bush to propose increased income tax rates as part of a program of revenue enhancement. Rather, the Kansas lawmaker said he expects Bush to seek to raise oil import fees and taxes on alcohol and tobacco. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., said such an approach clearly would not boost federal income enough to reduce mountainous budget deficits. Moynihan said Democrats were ready to precipitate a $100 billion forced spending cut next Oct. 1, as required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit spending law, if Bush does not increase income taxes and reduce the Social Security payroll deduction. New York Gov. Mario Cuomo said, meanwhile, that he believes the top tax rate should be raised from its present level of 28 percent to reduce the budget deficit. While the Democratic governor and prospective presidential contender was not specific, he cited 33 percent and 35 percent as targets for a new top tax rate. Dole and Moynihan commented on the ABC television program, ``This Week With David Brinkley.'' Cuomo was interviewed on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' On the CBS-TV program ``Face the Nation,'' Republican political pollster Linda DiVall said Bush's apparent reversal on the tax issue had angered many Republicans. ``There's been a lot of outrage this week. I don't recall a time where I've seen more anger within the Republican Party over how a president has led on a very important topic,'' she said. ``At the same time, I think many people are saying, `He must know something more than we do. What comes next?' '' She said it was apparent that the administration had miscalculated potential public reaction to talk of taxes. ``I think they underestimated how clearly that `no new taxes'' mantra rang throughout the country, how much people wanted to believe that,'' she said. Dole acknowledged that the president's new willingness to consider ``tax revenue increases'' is not popular. ``But I think there are enough of us in Congress to put a package together,'' even though it will be ``tough to pass,'' he said. Moynihan said he believes a five-year agreement should be reached that includes putting Social Security back on a pay-as-you-go basis ``and stop using that regressive payroll tax.'' Moynihan is proposing reducing the Social Security payroll tax while stopping the government from using surplus Social Security revenues to pay for other programs and, allegedly, to hide the true size of the budget deficit. Asked if Bush is now committed to tax increases, Dole replied: ``I think the president will not go along with an increase in tax rates.'' Dole said most Americans believe a tax hike has occurred when a larger bite is taken out of their pay check. He said he believes the increased tax revenue will come from an oil import fee or from ``sin taxes'' such as those on tobacco products and alcohol. Asked if he believes Bush is committed to such tax increases, Dole replied: ``Oh, he's committed, no question about it.'' ``You can't get there that way, Bob,'' Moynihan said. Dole was asked if Bush would veto an increase in income tax rates at any bracket. ``I'm not saying he would veto it,'' Dole said. ``The president now in a statesmanlike way has said, `OK, let's take a look at revenues.' Now the Democrats are coming back and saying, `Oh, good, we got him on revenues. Now let's take a bigger chunk out of defense.'' Moynihan was asked if Democrats will be the first to propose an actual specific tax increase. ``No,'' he replied. ``Our proposal is to cut Social Security and give every working family in this country an extra thousand dollars in income,'' he said. ``After that we can talk about other issues.'' Addressing Dole directly, Moynihan appeared to speak for other Democrats when he said: ``You have a right to tell the president this: If he's as committed as you think, he's headed for a crisis, he's headed for a sequester, $100 billion on the first of October _ and close down the national airports.'' Moynihan was asked if it is not more likely that the Gramm-Rudman requirements will not merely be loosened and liberalized before the Oct. 1 deadline. ``I would have to say to my friend ... Bob, don't count on us to change the number,'' Moynihan said. He was asked if the Democrats were ``ready to play chicken, to go right for the cliff.'' ``If you want to call it that, yeah,'' Moynihan replied.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Welcomes Economic Union, Citizens Apear Mixed
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Monika Pein mailed a letter to a friend in the United States Sunday, describing the incredible pace of events in the two Germanys, and stamped it with a commemorative imprint from the Post Office. ``I have just written in the letter that I really cannot grasp that we (Germany) will again be together,'' said Mrs. Pein, who was born near what is now Wroclaw, Poland. Her husband was born in East Germany, near Halle. ``We think about this every day. I really cannot believe this,'' she said. ``I had not thought that in my life _ I'm over 50 _ I would live to see this.'' Chancellor Helmut Kohl called the economic merger of the two Germanys that took effect Sunday ``the decisive step on the way to the unity of our fatherland, a big day in the history of the German nation.'' But not everyone shared the enthusiasm, and the day marking the first and most difficult step to unification passed with little fanfare in this West German capital. The Post Office kept special hours so people could have their mail stamped with an oval commemorative imprint noting July 1 as the day economic, monetary and social union between East Germany and West Germany took effect. But a postal worker said it was publicized too late to attract many people, and only about 80 people had stopped by in the first few hours. Reaction among West Germans to the economic merger with East Germany and eventual full unification was varied. Some, like Mrs. Pein, are realizing a dream; others say it is happening too fast and worry what it could cost; still others, especially younger people, feel little kinship with their brothers to the East. Manfred Brocker, a 43-year-old native of Bonn who says he's documented political changes over the years with stamps, collected one more for this historic day, but had mixed feelings. ``Basically, it's good,'' he said of the economic merger and upcoming unification. ``But people are only talking about East Germany and not at all about the West Germans. Nobody knows what it will cost us or if it will be good with the currency.'' ``One worries that it's happening much too fast,'' he said, complaining there was too little information from the government over what problems might result. And he was also not sure how alike the Germans were after 40 years of separation. ``It's a completely different generation,'' he said. ``Perhaps in 20 years'' the differences will be blurred, he said, ``but not so fast.'' Detlef Bloss, born in Weimar, the small East German town that was capital of Germany's first attempt at representative democracy, said he was worried a ``catastrophe'' in East Germany could result because of the large numbers of expected unemployed. Experts have predicted that anywhere from 500,000 to 4 million East Germans could lose their jobs as state subsidies fall to a market economy. One-third of all businesses are not expected to survive. ``I don't know that it's right. It's all so sudden,'' said Bloss, who fled to West Germany in 1978. ``The mentality is different, and the two (economic) systems are different.'' ``The people in East Germany are very greedy toward Western money, but they don't know what the future will bring. That is the problem, that is the worry I have.''
